整≲ਾ††††††††椼杭椠㵤瀢潲畤瑣浉条䵥摯污浉≧猠捲∽•污㵴䤢慭敧⁮敤⁬牰摯捵潴•汣獡㵳椢杭昭畬摩•瑳汹㵥洢硡栭楥桧㩴〶桶∻氠慯楤杮∽慬祺㸢 †††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳洢⵴∳ਾ††††††††††瀼椠㵤瀢潲畤瑣浉条䵥摯污牐捩≥挠慬獳∽扭〭㸢⼼㹰 †††††††㰠搯癩ਾ††††††⼼楤㹶 †††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳洢摯污昭潯整≲ਾ††††††††愼栠敲㵦⌢•摩∽牰摯捵䥴慭敧潍慤䉬祵•汣獡㵳戢湴戠湴甭楮散瑮潲•慴杲瑥∽扟慬歮•敲㵬渢潯数敮≲猠祴敬∽楤灳慬㩹潮敮∻䌾浯牰牡⼼㹡 †††††††㰠畢瑴湯琠灹㵥戢瑵潴≮挠慬獳∽瑢⁮瑢⵮敳潣摮牡≹搠瑡ⵡ獢搭獩業獳∽潭慤≬䌾牥慲㱲戯瑵潴㹮 †††††㰠搯癩ਾ††††⼼楤㹶 †㰠搯癩ਾ⼼楤㹶㰊ⴡ‭潍慤⁬半洠癯摥琠⁯獡敳獴樯⽳癥湥⹴獪ⴠ㸭ਊ猼牣灩㹴⼊ 慄潴⁳敤⁬癥湥潴瀠牡⁡畦据潩慮楬慤⁤敤挠污湥慤楲੯楷摮睯攮敶瑮慄慴㴠笠琢瑩敬㨢匢䝕剅久䥃十䈠䑏十尠摵㌸層摵㥣尲摵㌸層摵㡣≤∬慤整㨢㈢㈰ⴶ㄰〭∱∬潬慣楴湯㨢∢∬敤捳楲瑰潩≮∺敆档㩡〠就〯就㈯㈰∶∬牵≬∺⽜牰橯捥獴⽜湵捩湥牴屯支敶瑮獯⽜㉶⽜癥湥潴⽜畳敧敲据慩⵳潢慤⵳搵晥㥣㕡索਻⼼捳楲瑰ਾ昼潯整⁲汣獡㵳昢潯整≲ാ †㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢湯慴湩牥㸢਍††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潲⁷潲⵷慧⵰∳ാ †††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢汯氭ⵧ∲ാ †††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳昢潯整⵲潬潧㸢਍††††††††††椼杭猠捲∽瑨灴⼺氯捯污潨瑳瀯潲敪瑣⽳湵捩湥牴⽯癥湥潴⽳㉶愯獳瑥⽳浩条獥氯杯⹯湰≧愠瑬∽㸢਍††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潣⵬杬㐭挠汯洭ⵤ∶ാ †††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳昢潯整⵲楴汴ⵥ楷桴挭湯整瑮㸢਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潣瑮湥≴ാ †††††††††††㰠㍨匾捵牵慳⁬敃瑮潲⼼㍨ാ †††††††††††㰠㹰慐浬⁡獥⹱ㄠ‵敤䄠潧瑳㱯瀯ാ †††††††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢湯整瑮㸢਍††††††††††††格㸳桓灯楰杮䴠牡獩慣㱬栯㸳਍††††††††††††瀼儾敵慳慤㔠㔰‰⽣䌠慨汲獥搠⁥慇汵敬䈠潬畱⁥㱂瀯ാ †††††††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢汯氭ⵧ‴潣⵬摭㘭㸢਍††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潦瑯牥琭瑩敬眭瑩⵨潣瑮湥≴ാ †††††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢湯整瑮㸢਍††††††††††††格㸳桓灯楰杮䌠湥畴祲䰠浡慢썲㲩栯㸳਍††††††††††††瀼䄾⹶䌠捡煩敵䰠浡慢썲₩湥牴⁥才牡捡祡뫃礠吠獥慴潮慶⼼㹰਍††††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潣瑮湥≴ാ †††††††††††㰠㍨匾湡䰠牯湥潺⼼㍨ാ †††††††††††㰠㹰癁‮潒牤杩敵⁺敤䘠慲据慩㔠㔳挠 畊楬⁡楍慲摮⁡畃瑥㱯瀯ാ †††††††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††㰠搯癩ാ †††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢汯氭ⵧ∲ാ †††††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳猢捯慩⵬捩湯㸢਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽慦散潢歯㸢਍††††††††††††愼栠敲㵦栢瑴獰⼺眯睷昮捡扥潯⹫潣⽭湵捩湥牴灯≹琠牡敧㵴弢汢湡≫ാ †††††††††††††㰠浩⁧牳㵣栢瑴㩰⼯潬慣桬獯⽴牰橯捥獴甯楮散瑮潲支敶瑮獯瘯⼲獡敳獴椯慭敧⽳捩湯昭捡扥潯⹫癳≧愠瑬∽慦散潢歯㸢਍††††††††††††⼼㹡਍††††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽湩瑳≡ാ †††††††††††㰠⁡牨晥∽瑨灴㩳⼯睷⹷湩瑳条慲⹭潣⽭湵捩湥牴灯≹琠牡敧㵴弢汢湡≫ാ †††††††††††††㰠浩⁧牳㵣栢瑴㩰⼯潬慣桬獯⽴牰橯捥獴甯楮散瑮潲支敶瑮獯瘯⼲獡敳獴椯慭敧⽳捩湯椭獮慴献杶•污㵴椢獮慴牧浡㸢਍††††††††††††⼼㹡਍††††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽楬歮楤≮ാ †††††††††††㰠⁡牨晥∽瑨灴㩳⼯睷⹷楬歮摥湩挮浯振浯慰祮甯楮散瑮潲•慴杲瑥∽扟慬歮㸢਍††††††††††††††椼杭猠捲∽瑨灴⼺氯捯污潨瑳瀯潲敪瑣⽳湵捩湥牴⽯癥湥潴⽳㉶愯獳瑥⽳浩条獥椯潣⵮楬歮摥湩献杶•污㵴氢湩摫湩㸢਍††††††††††††⼼㹡਍††††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††††††搼癩挠慬獳∽桷瑡慳灰㸢਍††††††††††††愼栠敲㵦栢瑴獰⼺眯⹡敭㔯㔹㠹ㄵ㤳㠶㼹整瑸䌽湯畳瑬獡猠扯敲䔠敶瑮獯唠楮散瑮潲ⴠ圠扥•琠牡敧㵴弢汢湡≫ാ †††††††††††††㰠浩⁧牳㵣栢瑴㩰⼯潬慣桬獯⽴牰橯捥獴甯楮散瑮潲支敶瑮獯瘯⼲獡敳獴椯慭敧⽳捩湯眭慨獴灡⹰癳≧愠瑬∽桷瑡慳灰㸢਍††††††††††††⼼㹡਍††††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††⼼楤㹶਍††††搼癩挠慬獳∽潲≷ാ †††††㰠楤⁶汣獡㵳挢灯特杩瑨挭湯整瑮琠硥⵴散瑮牥洠⵴∴ാ †††††††㰠㉨㰾⁡牨晥∽瑨灴㩳⼯睷⹷湵捩湥牴⹯潣⹭祰㼯瑵彭潳牵散攽敶瑮獯甦浴浟摥畩㵭潦瑯牥损楬正•慴杲瑥∽扟楬歮㸢潖癬牥愠氠⁡楴湥慤眠扥⼼㹡⼼㉨ാ †††††††㰠㹰☠ㄣ㤶※湕捩湥牴⹯⼼㹰਍††††††⼼楤㹶਍††††⼼楤㹶਍††⼼楤㹶਍⼼潦瑯牥ാഊ㰊捳楲瑰猠捲∽瑨灴㩳⼯摣⹮獪敤楬牶渮瑥港浰戯潯獴牴灡㕀㌮㔮搯獩⽴獪戯潯獴牴灡戮湵汤⹥業⹮獪ഢ †††挠潲獳牯杩湩∽湡湯浹畯≳㰾猯牣灩㹴਍猼牣灩⁴牳㵣栢瑴㩰⼯潬慣桬獯⽴牰橯捥獴甯楮散瑮潲支敶瑮獯瘯⼲獡敳獴樯⽳畣瑳浯樮≳㰾猯牣灩㹴਍猼牣灩⁴牳㵣栧瑴獰⼺振湤樮摳汥癩⹲敮⽴灮⽭煪敵祲㍀㐮ㄮ搯獩⽴煪敵祲洮湩樮❳㰾猯牣灩㹴猼牣灩⁴牳㵣栧瑴獰⼺振湤樮摳汥癩⹲敮⽴灮⽭潢瑯瑳慲⵰慤整楰正牥ㅀㄮ⸰⼰楤瑳樯⽳潢瑯瑳慲⵰慤整楰正牥洮湩樮❳㰾猯牣灩㹴猼牣灩⁴牳㵣栧瑴獰⼺振湤樮摳汥癩⹲敮⽴灮⽭潢瑯瑳慲⵰慤整楰正牥ㅀㄮ⸰⼰楤瑳氯捯污獥戯潯獴牴灡搭瑡灥捩敫⹲獥洮湩樮❳㰾猯牣灩㹴猼牣灩⁴牳㵣栧瑴㩰⼯潬慣桬獯⽴牰橯捥獴甯楮散瑮潲支敶瑮獯瘯⼲獡敳獴樯⽳癥湥⹴獪瘿⸱✰㰾猯牣灩㹴⼼潢祤ാ㰊栯浴㹬 title: Halluciations

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.0 both client and server
- OS Version: Server = Linux / Client = Windows

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Tested with both code and code-insiders serving a tunnel from within a linux server
2. Tested under authentication through microsoft provider as well as github provider 
3. Tested both from local windows vscode client and also vscode.dev in the browser
4. Remote server always appears online for selection under the provider (Microsoft or github) being used for the test
5. "Connecting to remote ..." keeps spinning for minutes until it definitely fails with websockets related error (1006) in desktop version of vscode or error connecting to relay
6. No specific error logs appear at the remote server 

The tunnel has been working reliable until a few hours ago, when it stopped working. 

I've tested so many combinations that I do not know which logs or evidences to attach. Let me know what should I provide, please.
title: Remote tunnels stopped working

title: stuck

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I am using VS Code profiles to manage extensions on a language/framework-specific basis. But currently, for instance, I have a profile for SQL/Database specific extensions and also a profile for BE development in, let's say Java that contains Java specific extensions. I also have the Base profile that contains general extensions that I am always using (themes etc...)
Currently, I have to create all other profiles for language/framework from the Base profile and add the specific extension afterward.
In the case of Java profile, I am forced to add the SQL/Database specific profile extensions duplicitously and manually. This is super annoying, especially when I need to add/"inherit" extensions from multiple different profiles, let's say Y and Z, into profile X...

So the question is, would it be possible to add a feature that would allow you to enable multiple profiles at once?
The absolutely best scenario would be if on the top of that, the profiles could be enabled automatically based on user-specified rules. For example, something like "When file.java is encountered, activate 'Java profile'" and/or "When .sql file is encountered, activate 'SQL/Database' profile". And the Base profile would be always active...

Is something like this real?
Or perhaps is there already an existing alternative functionality, or maybe an extension (possibly 3party one)?
Thank you!
title: Simultaneous activation of multiple VS Code profiles for Extension management.

body: We have to expand the whole sidebar width just to see the full folder's name, it feels obnoxious. Having the ability to change the display of it how we desire would be great. In my case I would like to simply remove `Folders: ` The active icon in the activity bar is already my display of what I should be looking at. Plus is there's already folders displayed, then its even more obvious what I'm looking at, no need to label it. Someone already recommended this [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/169809) and the maintainers said they are happy to reconsider and I believe it has to be reconsidered. More flexibility is always welcome, especially since we can do it on the window title already.
title: Customize the Primary Sidebar's title

body:
**Problem:**
When using GitHub Copilot in Agent mode with the Gemini 2.5 Pro model, requests fail with the error "400 Bad Request." This does not happen with other models or when using Ask mode with Gemini 2.5 Pro. The error message includes a request ID for reference.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open VS Code with GitHub Copilot extension installed.
2. Select Agent mode and choose Gemini 2.5 Pro as the model.
3. Make a request (e.g., ask a question or request code generation).
4. Observe the error: "Request Failed: 400 Bad Request."

**Expected behavior:**
Requests should succeed as they do with other models and in Ask mode.

**Actual behavior:**
Requests in Agent mode with Gemini 2.5 Pro fail with a 400 Bad Request error.

**Screenshots:**
![Error screenshot in Agent mode with Gemini 2.5 Pro](https://github.com/github-copilot/chat/attachments/558477bc-95dc-4146-963c-8d1d75609484)

**Additional information:**
- The error only occurs in Agent mode with Gemini 2.5 Pro.
- Other models and Ask mode work correctly.
- Request ID: b635a8b5-9f4a-4dcc-a3c1-0ff024008bb1

**Environment:**
- GitHub Copilot extension (latest)
- VS Code (latest)
- OS: Linux (zsh terminal shown)

**Troubleshooting steps taken:**
- Logged out and back into GitHub account
- Reinstalled Copilot extension
- Cleared VS Code cache folders manually
- Issue persists after all steps above

**Please investigate if this is a backend issue, a compatibility bug, or if further user-side steps are required. If logs or more info are needed, please specify what to provide.

comments.body: This issue is a duplicate of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/253136. Please refer to that issue for updates and discussions. Feel free to open a new issue if you think this is a different problem.

body:
**Summary:**

For the past two months, I've been using Copilot (Pro version, premium quota models) for code improvement in VS Code. Instead of improving my code, these models have consistently broken all submitted code versions—introducing duplicated functions, unresolved errors, and leaving projects incomplete. Each attempt at a solution only pretends to address the issues, ultimately waiting out the premium quota period without providing real fixes or finishing the work. 

**Impact:**
- Wasted significant time and money with no real resolutions.
- The only way forward seems to be waiting for quota renewal (after 30 days) or upgrading to more expensive subscriptions, with no actual guarantee that higher tiers deliver better results.
- It feels like a deliberate strategy to push users toward costly upgrades without true improvements to model quality or reliability.

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Use Copilot Pro models with premium quota for code enhancement tasks.
2. Observe that code is broken, functions are duplicated, and issues remain unresolved.
3. Attempts to fix problems only cycle until quota ends or prompt paid upgrades.

**VS Code Version:** 
**OS Version:** 
**Copilot Chat Extension Version:** 
**Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):** 
**Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):** 
**Logs:**

**Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?:** Yes/No

**Additional Feedback:**
This pattern seems widespread and not limited to my case. Please clarify if this is intended behavior or a known bug, and provide actionable steps for resolution without requiring further paid upgrades.

title: bug detect failiure

body:
# Info
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (It requires the Python and Pylance extensions, but the issue persists even after extension bisect, indicating a core issue with Pylance's path handling.)

# Version
VS Code Version: 1.104.3 (user setup)
Commit: 385651c938df8a906869babee516bffd0ddb9829
Date: 2025-10-02T12:30:51.747Z
Electron: 37.3.1
ElectronBuildId: 12404162
Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
Node.js: 22.18.0
V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
OS: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.22631.5909]

Pylance Fails to Resolve Imports from Virtual Environment (eventlet.wsgi) Despite Correct Interpreter Selection
# Steps to Reproduce:

Create and Populate Virtual Environment:

On Windows, create a venv (or conda/Poetry environment): python -m venv myenv.

Activate the environment.

Install a package: pip install eventlet.

Open VS Code and Select Interpreter:

Open the project folder containing the myenv directory.

Use Python: Select Interpreter from the Command Palette (`Ctrl+Shift+P`).

Explicitly select the virtual environment's executable: C:\path\to\myenv\Scripts\python.exe.

# Attempt Import:

Create a Python file (app.py) and add the import statement:

Python

`import eventlet.wsgi`
Observe Pylance Error:

Observe the editor immediately show the error: Import "eventlet.wsgi" could not be resolvedPylancereportMissingImports.

# Verify Execution (Conflicting Result):

Open the VS Code integrated terminal, ensure the myenv environment is activated, and run the file: python app.py.

The program executes successfully without any import errors, confirming the module is installed and functional within the selected environment.

Expected Behavior
Pylance should correctly inspect the site-packages directory of the explicitly selected interpreter (C:\path\to\myenv\Scripts\python.exe) and successfully resolve the eventlet.wsgi import.

title: off this feature dont show me suggestions

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

I believe that visual studio code should have a refresh button, most of the time many issues are solved my just reloading the window. Which I find counter productive because not only do I have close the current working file (which in some cases hampers my work or in middle of writing, obviously after saving ) or when I'm running some local server. 

Also visual studio code get heavy after working on it (like adding internal/external extensions), so in windows it gets painful to open it.  Thankfully I use Linux so I do not have much but my office computer is in windows so yeah.

By the way, I was not talking about the operating system issue rather the internal issues like copy paste not working, extensions not instantly working, updates getting stuck.

I believe adding a simple reload button or right-click reload option will work fine. Also while you are at it, make updates once or twice a month. 

Thank you

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.3 - OS Version: Windows 11 24H2 (OS Build 26100.6584) Steps to Reproduce: 1. Uninstall existing VS Code following the instructions here: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/setup/uninstall (go for the full Clean Uninstall) 2. Reboot (you might not have to, but I did) 3. Install VS Code 1.104.3 using the installer 4. Untick all the options (up to you, but I did) 5. Let the installer launch Visual Studio Code 6. Visit the extensions thing with Ctrl+Shift+X 7. Try to search for `rewrap` on the marketplace Expected result: you find, e.g., https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=stkb.rewrap Actual result: `Error while fetching extensions. Cannot read properties of undefined (reading 'identifier')` # Other notes * The same occurs when searching for `rewra`. * You can search for `rewr` and it finds stuff

comments.body: Don't know if it's related, but GitHub Settings Sync hasn't synced this plugin for me (which was what got me investigating this in the first place).
Also noted with VS Code 1.104.3 on macOS 15.7.1.

Noticed later on VS Code 1.104.3/macOS 15.7.1, after letting it sync settings and whatnot (and having it fail to install the stkb.rewrap extension that I wanted): I searched for `rewr` in the marketplace as above, and found that despite the greyed-out Install button for stkb.rewrap, I could right click on its entry and manually install it. I had to click through a messagebox to let it install, because it's unsigned. And when I search for `rewrap` now, it finds stuff. I'll be able to try this on my Windows 11 PC later.

above is the details of the VScode and the problem still persists

Can you follow these steps so that we can get more information on what's going on?

#### Enable trace logging

* Open the Command Palette (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Trace`, click the *double* check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (enables trace logging as the default)

_Now wait for the issue to happen or trigger it..._

#### Getting the logs

* Open the Command Palette again (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Output: Show Output Channels...` command
* Choose `GitHub Authentication`
* Copy and paste the contents of what opens in the panel in this issue (if the contents is too large, you may need to upload it as a file)

#### Reverting trace logging (optional)

When we're done here, to revert the log level back to the default:
* Open the Command Palette
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Info`, click the double check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (to set the default back to info)

body:

title: Crashed, no response was returned

body:
Hello VSCode Core Team / Community,

I’ve been exploring the architecture of microsoft/vscode and its extension ecosystem. What I observe is a recurring structural deficiency: extension communication paths and command relays are being treated implicitly rather than as first-class expression protocols. This weakens control, traceability, and reliability.

Problems Observed

Extensions send messages via generic channels (e.g. vscode.commands.executeCommand(...)) without exposing their expression origin / call context.

No protocol layer differentiates user intent command vs automated relay; thus recovery / rollback paths are absent when chained commands fail silently.

Extensions sometimes override behavior without passing through a controlled expression routing layer, making “who did what in chain” opaque.

State sync between extension host and UI (webview / tree views / panels) lacks structured metadata, causing mismatch and race condition blind spots.

 Real-world Enterprise Scenarios

These structural weaknesses become critical liabilities in enterprise-scale deployments:

 Multi-extension environments (20+ extensions across teams) often suffer from command collisions, override conflicts, or unexpected execution chains — but lack tools to audit causality.

When bugs arise in deeply chained behaviors (e.g. Extension A triggers B, which triggers C...), DevOps teams cannot trace root causes due to missing expression metadata.

 CI/CD pipelines leveraging VSCode in containerized build agents (e.g. GitHub Codespaces, devcontainers) may fail silently or inconsistently, with no structured chain of responsibility to debug.

Product managers and IT admins can’t analyze usage/intent behind behaviors, making governance of extension approval / review / rollback impossible at scale.

Without expression protocol metadata, enterprise DevOps pipelines, security review processes, and multi-team development environments are flying blind.

Why this matters

Traceability: Extension chains become unauditable black boxes — a critical risk for enterprises.

Stability: One faulty extension can break invisible relay paths, corrupt UI state, or hijack core behavior.

Security: Without expression origin tracing, command injection risks go unnoticed.

Governance: Enterprises need structured behavioral maps to approve, review, and revoke capabilities across extensions.

Without an Expression Communication Protocol, VSCode’s extension ecosystem remains best-effort, rather than robust, accountable, and scalable.

 Suggestion: Introduce an Expression Communication Protocol (ECP)

A thin metadata layer wrapping extension-to-core and core-to-extension command calls, carrying structured expression fields.

command:
  name: extension.doSomething
  origin_extension: “my.ext.id”
  origin_intent: “user_invoke / auto_relay / conditional_trigger”
  expression_path: 
    - “UI.click.someAction”
    - “ExtensionA.onFocus”
    - “ExtensionA.invokeB”
fail_node: “listener.not.exist”
protocol_recovery_hint: “fallback to no-op or revert state”


This would enable:

Clear origin/intent audit trails

 Rollback & recovery hooks

 Governance overlays for extension chains

Enterprise usage attribution and safety reviews

Would the team be open to discussing a draft of such a protocol layer? I’d be happy to contribute an example from a governance-focused perspective.

Thanks for reading.

— Yuer / Expression‑Driven Architecture Researcher
title: Protocol Expression Gap in Extension Communication & Command Relay in VSCode Core

- VS Code Version: 1.104.2
- OS Version: Linux

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create `.vscode/settings.json`, `.vscode/extensions.json`, etc.
2. Put a comment into that "JSON", as allowed by https://jsonc.org, used [implicitly](https://github.com/microsoft/node-jsonc-parser) by VSC
3. Use any other of about a billion existing tool which assumes that `*.json` are https://www.json.org and not https://jsonc.org
4. See that tool fail, e.g. https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks/issues/1196

This was already reported in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/79744 over 6+ years ago. 

Would a PR to add support for this be welcome?

body: On the VSCode website https://code.visualstudio.com/ is a hero video showing a user using VSCode to create a website. The website in the video contains OpenStreetMap data. Such data is licensed under the [Open Data Commons Open Database License (ODbL)](https://opendatacommons.org/licenses/odbl/). You can find the details on https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright. Attribution is required to display the data. URL to video: https://code.visualstudio.com/assets/home/hero-dark-lg.webm. The licenced content is visible at 0:42. An example of attribution: This issue is a request to adhere to the data license requirements, and update the VSCode hero video to include attribution like required in the license.

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

In the superrepo, with the following `.git/config`
```
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = false
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	symlinks = false
	ignorecase = true
[remote "origin"]
	url = https://github.com/Gravifer/lean-mathlib-1stproj.git
	fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
[branch "main"]
	remote = origin
	merge = refs/heads/main
	vscode-merge-base = origin/main
[submodule "mil"]
	url = https://github.com/Gravifer/lean-comm.mathematics_in_lean.git
	active = true
[submodule "mpil"]
	url = https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean4-metaprogramming-book.git
	active = true
```
and `.gitmodules`
```
[submodule "mil"]
	path = LeanMathlib1stproj/mil
	url = https://github.com/Gravifer/lean-comm.mathematics_in_lean.git
[submodule "mpil"]
	path = LeanMathlib1stproj/mpil/foo
	url = https://github.com/leanprover-community/lean4-metaprogramming-book.git
```
The SCM panel shows the second submodule with the name `foo`, as it determines the name using only the submodule root dirname (impressing skimming the source code). Upon the situation where the tags have been customized, it can be more informant to use the configured tag; the behavior can be left unaltered should the tag is left auto-generated, as it would just be the relative path to the submodule root.
title: Respect submodule names defined in superrepo's `.gitmodules` file

Thanks for creating this issue! We figured it's missing some basic information or in some other way doesn't follow our [issue reporting guidelines](https://aka.ms/vscodeissuereporting). Please take the time to review these and update the issue.

For Copilot Issues, be sure to visit our [Copilot-specific guidelines](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Copilot-Issues) page for details on the necessary information.

Happy Coding!

body: > Adding a workaround that retries the chat request with Node.js' fetch. > > Verification on macOS or Linux: > - Filter for `node-fetch` in the Chat output channel. > - Start a chat session. (E.g., a longwinded Ask session to make timing easy.) > - In the middle of a streamed reply enable Azure VPN. (That's the easiest way I know of.) > - Verify you see the following two messages in the output channel: > ``` > [info] Retrying chat request with node-fetch after net::ERR_NETWORK_CHANGED error. > [debug] FetcherService: using node-fetch as requested. > ``` > > Make sure the chat panel keeps rendering correctly. The partial response will roll back when the error occurs and the response from the retry will start streaming in. > I followed these steps and did this during Tool Optimization and got: _Originally posted by @chrmarti in [#260297](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/260297#issuecomment-3365549325)_

body:
# Persistent Phantom Commits in Source Control Panel for Git Repositories

## Bug Description

VS Code's Source Control panel displays persistent phantom commits that do not exist in the actual Git repository state. These phantom commits show specific commit messages (e.g., "UV package installation warning - missing RECORD file Fixes No. 9") that cannot be committed (commit button is grayed out) and do not correspond to any actual changes in the repository.

## Environment Information

- **Copilot Chat Extension Version**: Latest (as of October 3, 2025)
- **VS Code Version**: Latest stable
- **OS Version**: Windows 11
- **Feature**: Source Control Management (SCM) / Git integration
- **Selected model**: Claude 3.7 Sonnet (GitHub Copilot)

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Open a workspace containing multiple Git repositories (including submodules)
2. Perform normal Git operations (commits, branch switches, submodule updates)
3. Work with GitHub Copilot in the workspace
4. Observe the Source Control panel showing phantom commits with specific messages
5. Note that:
   - The commit message appears in the Source Control panel
   - The commit button is grayed out/disabled
   - `git status` in terminal shows "nothing to commit, working tree clean"
   - The phantom commit persists across:
     - VS Code restarts
     - Workspace reloads
     - Git operations (reset, checkout, etc.)
     - Complete repository recreation
     - GitHub Copilot extension removal and reinstallation

## Expected Behavior

The Source Control panel should only display actual Git changes that exist in the repository. When `git status` shows a clean working tree, the Source Control panel should show no pending commits.

## Actual Behavior

The Source Control panel persistently shows phantom commits with specific messages like:

- "UV package installation warning - missing RECORD file Fixes No. 9"

These phantom commits:

- Cannot be committed (button is grayed out)
- Do not correspond to any actual repository changes
- Persist indefinitely regardless of Git operations or VS Code restarts
- Appear to be generated or cached commit messages that have become disconnected from actual repository state

## Troubleshooting Attempted

### Git-level troubleshooting

- Verified `git status` shows clean working tree
- Performed `git reset --hard HEAD`
- Switched branches multiple times
- Removed and recreated problematic repositories
- Removed Git lock files (`.git/index.lock`)
- Created fresh clones of repositories

### VS Code troubleshooting

- Restarted VS Code multiple times
- Reloaded workspace (`Developer: Reload Window`)
- Completely uninstalled and reinstalled GitHub Copilot extensions
- Attempted to disable Git extension (but this is built-in)

### Repository-level troubleshooting

- Completely removed and recreated Git submodules
- Verified all repositories show clean state in command line Git
- Confirmed phantom commits don't exist in actual Git history
- Tested with fresh repository clones

## Additional Context

- This issue appears to be related to VS Code's Git extension caching or state management
- The phantom commit messages seem to be AI-generated suggestions that have become "stuck"
- The issue persists across repository recreations, suggesting it's a VS Code extension state issue rather than a Git repository issue
- Multiple repositories in the same workspace show similar phantom commit behavior
- The actual Git repositories are completely clean and functional when accessed via command line

## Impact

This bug makes the Source Control panel unreliable and confusing, as it displays non-existent commits that cannot be resolved through normal Git operations. It suggests changes that don't exist and cannot be committed, creating a poor user experience.

## Logs

Terminal verification shows clean Git state:

```bash
PS C:\Users\drewa\My Drive\Claude Code Workspace> git status
On branch main
Your branch is up to date with 'origin/main'.

nothing to commit, working tree clean
```

While VS Code Source Control panel simultaneously shows phantom commits for the same repository.

## Request

Please investigate VS Code's Git extension state management and caching mechanisms, particularly around:

1. How commit messages are generated and cached
2. Integration between GitHub Copilot and Git extension state
3. Proper cleanup of cached Git state when repositories are modified or recreated

This appears to be a state synchronization issue between VS Code's Git extension and the actual repository state.
title: Persistent Phantom Commits in Source Control Panel for Git Repositories

comments.body: @rperez030 I noticed that when I log what we're alerting, all the messages are present. But when I enable the screen reader, only some are read. I believe this is a timing issue. Using `status` vs `alert` did not fix it. Any suggestions? Not sure if there's anything we can do about it.

We alert with tool messages here:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/e058641feb9bf97795022f07273ca5ffd755c39f/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/languageModelToolsService.ts#L338

<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (duh)

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.3 (see below)
- OS Version: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 (see below)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Install extension X from VSIX
2. Uninstall extension
3. Install extension X from Marketplace
4. Reload VSCode window
5. Observe the extension X showing "This extension is no longer available on the Extension Marketplace."

Comments:

1) I'd accept that if I install from VSIX you would show some kind of message (perhaps about auto-update disabled? who knows...), but the current messaging is misleading. I can uninstall the VSIX and got to Marketplace and get it! 

2) When I uninstall the VSIX one and install from Marketplace, then it's completely foolish to say " This extension is no longer available on the Extension Marketplace." -- I literally just installed it from there, right?

I think this is a bug.

---

comments.body: * https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/269737

- VS Code Version: v1.104.3 - Operating System: Windows 11 Pro on amd64 - Code Installation: Very New Reinstallation This morning, I started experiencing this issue with **many** extensions, including many I have installed, as well as many still _on_ the Marketplace, whenever I search for something in the `Extensions` sidebar view. In my case, however, it started occurring after manually copying some data files from a previous (Code) installation into the profile's `globalStorage` folder for the extension the files were for. That is, into `~\AppData\Roaming\Code\Users\profiles\ProfileName\globalStorage`. After copying them, I reloaded the window and noticed a lot of the triangular yellow icons (with a bang inside) as a badge in the aforementioned view. Also, maybe relevant, maybe not, but at first when when hovering over the extensions, the pop-up said "VS Code this extension is no longer acceptable on the Extension Marketplace." instead of "..._unavailable_ on the Marketplace." This, however, may be due to my own misreading of the badge at first. But I'm probably 85% sure it said "unacceptable" first, before changing to "unavailable"...maybe I'm just tired. Anyway, GL on your end. I'm gonna keep investigating on my break, but for now it seems the effected extensions (the ones I have installed, at least) still function properly, and I don't have a _lot_ of time, so it'll have to wait.
Same issue, reinstalling Visual Studio Code doesn’t solve it, it actually makes it worse. When importing the backed-up profiles, these extensions are not restored.

body: When allow list policy is set, many extensions in search result are often disabled/unavailable for install as shown in this example. However, users are unable to filter for only installable/enabled extensions. It's hard to scroll through long lists of unavailable extensions to find the ones available. Many Private Marketplace customers are planning to use upstreaming with allow list making this UX important. Allow list set: { "Contoso.contosocopilot": true, "Contoso.contosopack": true, "Contoso.contosooss": true, "microsoft": true, "github": true, "redhat": "stable", } Search results: Filter is not active:
title: Filter extension search-results for installable extensions

Open ask mode and type `@github #kb` This should bring up a list of knowledge bases (see https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/256450) for a recent example, but no longer does. title: spawn xterm ENOENT

body: I'm unable to select the first line due to there being errors in the C# file. Workaround: set a language-specific setting in the settings.json file. ``` "[csharp]": { "editor.stickyScroll.enabled": false } ```
title: Unable to edit first line of C# files while there are errors due to sticky scroll

Same issue with our extension. This seems to be intermittent.

Hi @sandy081,

We’re seeing the message *"This extension is no longer available on the Extension Marketplace."* (let’s call this the `removal message`). This doesn’t seem related to the VS Code version.

Here’s what we tested:
1. `Extension Query` works fine.
2. But `Latest Query` doesn’t return valid results, which seems to trigger the `removal message`.

We checked the VS Code source code and didn’t find anything unusual.
- Source code:  [v1.104.3 - extensionsActions.ts#L2611-L2614](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/1.104.3/src/vs/workbench/contrib/extensions/browser/extensionsActions.ts#L2611-L2614)

Do you know why only our extension fails to return info from Azure DevOps?  
Could this be due to some internal MS policy preventing our extension from being published?

We haven’t received any notice or email about this. If that’s the case, shouldn’t we have been informed beforehand?

---

### Test Details

#### 1. Extension Query (`extensionQuery`)

- **1-1. Query:**  
```sh
curl -X POST https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/_apis/public/gallery/extensionquery \
  -H "Accept: application/json;api-version=7.2-preview" \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{
    "filters": [
      {
        "criteria": [
          { "filterType": 7, "value": "infradise.visualkube" }
        ]
      }
    ],
    "flags": 914
  }'
```

- **1-2. Result:**  
```json
{"results": [
    {"extensions": [ 
        {"publisher": { "flags": "verified", ...},
         "flags": "validated, public",
         "lastUpdated": "2025-09-26T09:12:05.02Z",
         "publishedDate": "2025-09-01T08:30:45.257Z",
         "releaseDate": "2025-09-01T08:30:45.257Z", ...}
```

#### 2. Latest Query (`latest`)

- **2-1. Query:**  
```sh
curl -i https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/_apis/public/gallery/vscode/infradise/visualkube/latest
```

- **2-2. Expected Result:**  
```json
{"publisher": { "flags": "verified", ...},
 "flags": "validated, public",
 "lastUpdated": "2025-09-26T09:12:05.02Z",
 "publishedDate": "2025-09-01T08:30:45.257Z",
 "releaseDate": "2025-09-01T08:30:45.257Z", ...}
```
 
- **2-3. Actual Result:**  
```json
{"count":1,"value":{"Message":"The requested extension 'infradise.visualkube' doesn't exist."}}
```

title: Command freezes

body:
Type: Bug 1. Install the PerplexityAI Copilot extension via GitHub Marketplace (https://github.com/marketplace/perplexityai) for your personal account. 2. In VS Code, sign out of GitHub and Copilot, then sign back in to ensure fresh authentication. 3. Open a workspace in VS Code and invoke Copilot Chat (Ctrl+Shift+P → “Chat: Open”). 4. Enter the prompt: @perplexityai что такое Python? 5. When prompted, click “Authorize” in the browser to grant the Copilot Chat (read) permission. 6. Return to VS Code and resend the same prompt. 7. Observe the error in Copilot Chat: Response contained no choices. 8. In VS Code Output panel (select “GitHub Copilot Chat”), observe repeated warnings: [warning] Bad response from remote agent "perplexityai": unknown Response contained no choices. 9. In Developer Tools console, you may see IPC and grammar warnings but no indication of local misconfiguration. Expected Result: PerplexityAI should return a valid answer instead of “Response contained no choices.” Actual Result: The extension consistently logs a “Bad response from remote agent ‘perplexityai’: unknown Response contained no choices” warning and provides no reply. Type: Bug Description: When typing in a .tex file with github copilot enabled, it displays a "Ctrl+I to continue with Copilot" ghost text after the cursor. If the cursor is at the end of a line (with word wrap turned on), the ghost text extends off-screen, which adds a horizontal scrollbar since the text is no longer fully visible. When you continue typing, it annoyingly shifts the view to the right by one character. Then, as the line wraps, the view stays shifted by one character to the right. If the copilot extension is disabled, this problem doesn't occur. Details: Font: Default Word wrap: on Steps to reproduce: 1. Enable copilot & word wrap, open a .tex file 2. Type a long line 3. At the end of the line, the "continue with Copilot" inline suggestion appears (which is too long to be fully displayed, so a horizontal scrollbar appears at the bottom) 4. Continue typing 5. Just before the line wraps, the view shifts to the right by one character; continue typing 6. body:
# AI Terminal Output Capture Consistently Loses Last Line (Cygwin Default Shell on Windows)

## Summary

When using GitHub Copilot's `run_in_terminal` tool with shell integration enabled, **the last line of terminal output is consistently lost** when using **Cygwin bash as the default shell** on Windows. This is a deterministic bug that occurs 100% of the time and severely impacts AI assistant functionality.

**Critical Context**: 
- Cygwin is the **default shell environment** for affected user
- User has **full AI permissions enabled** (unrestricted terminal access)
- Bug is **100% reproducible** across multiple AI models (Claude 4/4.5, GPT-5)
- Affects **50+ verified test cases** in various environments

**Note**: This appears to be a regression in recent Insiders builds. Earlier versions had different capture issues (frequent hangs), suggesting ongoing development in this area. See "Version History & Regression Notes" below for details.

## Environment

- **VS Code Version**: 1.105.0-insider (Insiders Build)
- **Commit**: e0dada76949dc8179d5c8e03f1bae491c0c2ec51
- **Date**: 2025-10-03T00:46:58.091Z
- **Electron**: 37.6.0
- **Chromium**: 138.0.7204.251
- **Node.js**: 22.19.0
- **OS**: Windows_NT x64 10.0.20348
- **Shell**: bash.exe (Cygwin)
- **Default Shell**: Cygwin bash

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Open VS Code Insiders with Cygwin bash as default terminal
2. Use GitHub Copilot or any tool that uses `run_in_terminal` with output capture
3. Execute a command that produces multiple lines of output:
   ```bash
   for i in {1..10}; do echo "$i: $RANDOM $RANDOM $RANDOM"; done
   ```
4. Observe the captured output

### Expected Behavior

All 10 lines should be captured:
```
1: 1234 5678 9012
2: 3456 7890 1234
...
10: 5678 9012 3456
```

### Actual Behavior

Only 9 lines are captured - **the last line is consistently missing**:
```
1: 1234 5678 9012
2: 3456 7890 1234
...
9: 2345 6789 0123
(line 10 is missing)
```

## Reproducibility

**100% reproducible** - extensively tested across multiple AI models and environments.

### Initial Testing (GitHub Copilot - Claude 4.5)

| Test | Expected Lines | Captured Lines | Missing Line |
|------|---------------|----------------|--------------|
| 1    | 12            | 11             | Last (#12)   |
| 2    | 15            | 14             | Last (#15)   |
| 3    | 10            | 9              | Last (#10)   |
| 4    | 13            | 12             | Last (#13)   |
| 5    | 11            | 10             | Last (#11)   |
| 6    | 14            | 13             | Last (#14)   |
| 7    | 10            | 9              | Last (#10)   |
| 8    | 15            | 14             | Last (#15)   |
| 9    | 12            | 11             | Last (#12)   |
| 10   | 14            | 13             | Last (#14)   |

**Pattern**: Always exactly the last line is lost, never middle lines.

### Cross-Verification Testing (2025-10-03)

To ensure this wasn't specific to one AI model, extensive verification was performed:

#### WITHOUT Workaround - Bug Confirmed Across Multiple Models:

| AI Model | Environment | Tests Run | Missing Last Line | Success Rate |
|----------|-------------|-----------|-------------------|--------------|
| GitHub Copilot (Claude 4.5) | Default workspace | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 0% |
| Claude 4 | New window, no workspace | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 0% |
| Claude 4 | Window with workspace | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 0% |
| Claude 4 | Long history session | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 0% |
| ChatGPT (GPT-5) | Multiple sessions | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 0% |

**Total**: 50+ tests across 5 different environments - **100% failure rate**

#### WITH Workaround - Fix Confirmed Across Multiple Models:

| AI Model | Tests Run | All Lines Captured | Success Rate |
|----------|-----------|-------------------|--------------|
| GitHub Copilot (Claude 4.5) | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 100% ✅ |
| Claude 4 | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 100% ✅ |
| Claude 4 (second test) | 10 | 10/10 (100%) | 100% ✅ |

**Total**: 30+ tests - **100% success rate with workaround**

### Key Observations:

1. **Bug is NOT AI-model specific** - affects Claude 4, Claude 4.5, GPT-5
2. **Bug is NOT environment specific** - occurs in new windows, workspaces, long sessions
3. **100% deterministic** - never seen a single exception across 50+ tests
4. **Workaround is 100% effective** - all 30+ tests with workaround succeeded
5. **Only affects Cygwin default shell** - user has full AI permissions enabled for terminal access

### Important Note on GPT-5 Behavior:

Some GPT-5 sessions exhibited different behavior:
- **Partial failures**: Some tests reported "output capture disabled" or hang-like behavior
- **Inconsistent results**: Different GPT-5 instances showed varying levels of capture failure
- This suggests GPT-5 may have stricter timeout or different capture integration, making the underlying bug more severe for some AI backends

**Environment Details**:
- Cygwin is the **default shell environment** for this user
- User has **full AI permissions** enabled (unrestricted terminal access)
- Shell integration is active and functional
- Testing performed on 2025-10-03 with latest VS Code Insiders build

## Root Cause Analysis

The issue appears to be a **buffer flush timing problem** in the shell integration's output capture mechanism:

1. VS Code's terminal integration uses shell integration hooks (likely OSC 633 sequences)
2. When a command completes, the output stream is closed
3. The last line doesn't get flushed to the capture buffer before the stream closes
4. This specifically affects Cygwin/bash which may have different buffering behavior than native Windows shells

## Workaround

Adding a `PROMPT_COMMAND` hook that outputs a completion marker **forces the buffer to flush** before capture stops:

```bash
debug_postexec() {
    local exit_code=$?
    
    # Execute original PROMPT_COMMAND
    if [[ -n "$ORIGINAL_PROMPT_COMMAND" ]]; then
        eval "$ORIGINAL_PROMPT_COMMAND"
    fi
    
    # KEY FIX: Output completion marker to stderr
    # This forces buffer flush before VS Code stops capturing
    echo "COMMAND-COMPLETE-${exit_code}" >&2
    
    return $exit_code
}

trap 'CMD_START_TIME=$(date '+%s.%N')' DEBUG
export PROMPT_COMMAND="debug_postexec"
```

**Result**: With this workaround, all 10/10 tests captured complete output including the last line.

### Complete Workaround Script

See attached: `vscode-terminal-output-capture-workaround.sh`

## Related Issues

This bug differs from previously reported issues:

- **#111930** - Missing last lines with large output (random, not consistent)
- **#136092** - Output trimmed when toggling panel
- **#252524** - WSL output not captured at all (empty output)
- **#253265** - `run_in_terminal` returns empty
- **#261585** - Process completion not detected

**This issue is unique because**:
- ✅ Deterministic (100% reproducible)
- ✅ Always exactly the last line (not random)
- ✅ Specific to Cygwin/bash shell integration
- ✅ Has a working workaround (shell hook forcing buffer flush)

## Impact

**Severity**: High - Critical for users with Cygwin as default shell

**Affected Users**:
- **Primary impact**: Users with Cygwin/bash as their **default Windows shell**
- This is a **production environment** for many developers who prefer Unix-like tooling on Windows
- Affects users who have granted **full AI terminal permissions** for enhanced productivity
- Bug renders AI terminal integration nearly unusable for this user base

**Functional Impact**:
- AI assistants cannot see final results of commands
- Test results are incomplete (final summary line often missing)
- Build completion messages lost
- Error messages on last line not captured
- Success/failure indicators frequently missing
- Severely degrades AI-assisted development workflow
- Makes AI debugging and troubleshooting unreliable

**Business Impact**:
- Users who switched to Cygwin as default shell for better Unix compatibility are penalized
- Undermines confidence in VS Code's AI features for Cygwin environments
- Forces users to either:
  - Give up Cygwin as default (major workflow disruption)
  - Work without reliable AI assistance (productivity loss)
  - Manually apply workarounds (complexity burden)

**Historical Context**: 
- This issue is part of an ongoing series of terminal output capture problems
- Earlier versions: Frequent hangs/freezes during output capture (worse but different)
- Current version: No hangs, but last line consistently lost (better but still broken)
- Shows VS Code team is actively working on this area, but capture reliability remains challenging

## Suggested Fix

The shell integration code should ensure all output buffers are properly flushed before closing the capture stream. Specifically:

1. Wait for final buffer flush after command completion
2. Add a small delay (10-50ms) before closing capture
3. Ensure `PROMPT_COMMAND` execution completes before capture ends
4. Handle Cygwin-specific buffering behavior

### Alternative: Built-in Workaround for Cygwin Users

Until the root cause is fixed, VS Code could automatically apply the workaround for Cygwin environments:

**Option A: Auto-inject via shell integration**
- Detect Cygwin/bash environment
- Automatically inject COMMAND-COMPLETE marker into `PROMPT_COMMAND`
- Only activate when `$TERM_PROGRAM == 'vscode'`

**Option B: Documentation for manual setup**
Add to VS Code documentation for Cygwin users to add to their `~/.bashrc`:

```bash
# VS Code terminal output capture fix for Cygwin
if [[ "$TERM_PROGRAM" == "vscode" ]]; then
    source /etc/profile.d/vscode-terminal-fix.sh 2>/dev/null || \
    source ~/.vscode-terminal-fix.sh 2>/dev/null
fi
```

**Option C: VS Code setting**
Add a setting like `"terminal.integrated.cygwin.enableOutputFix": true` that automatically applies the workaround when detected.

This would provide immediate relief for Cygwin users while the underlying buffer flush issue is being investigated and fixed properly.

## Version History & Regression Notes

**Important**: This appears to be a **regression in recent Insiders builds**.

### Previous Behavior (Earlier VS Code Version - exact version unknown)

In an earlier version of VS Code Insiders, the output capture had a **different but related problem**:
- The AI tool would frequently **hang/freeze** while attempting to capture terminal output
- The capture process would get stuck waiting indefinitely for output
- This made the feature practically unusable

### Attempted Fix Led to Current Issue

To work around the hanging problem, I developed a shell integration hook script with `PROMPT_COMMAND` that:
- Added command completion markers
- Provided timing information
- Attempted to signal when output was complete

**Critical Discovery**: In that earlier VS Code version, **the workaround script completely blocked output capture** - VS Code would receive no output at all when the script was active. This suggested that VS Code's capture mechanism was very sensitive to shell hooks interfering with its timing.

### Current Behavior (VS Code 1.105.0-insider)

The hanging issue appears to be **resolved**, but now we have a **different problem**:
- Output capture works and doesn't hang ✅
- BUT: The last line is consistently dropped ❌
- Interestingly, the **same workaround script now fixes the issue** instead of breaking it

**This suggests**:
1. Recent changes to shell integration have improved capture reliability (no more hangs)
2. BUT introduced a new buffer flush timing issue (last line lost)
3. The workaround that previously broke capture now helps it - indicating significant changes to the capture mechanism

## Additional Information

- Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: **Yes** (tested with only GitHub Copilot Chat enabled)
- The issue does NOT occur with individual `echo` commands run separately
- The issue ONLY occurs with multi-line output from a single command execution
- Shell integration IS working correctly (exit codes, working directory, etc.)
- **Regression**: Earlier version had hanging issues; current version has last-line-loss issues
- **Workaround paradox**: Script that blocked capture in earlier version now fixes it in current version


Suggested labels: terminal, shell-integration, bug, cygwin

---

**Attachments**:
- Workaround script: `vscode-terminal-output-capture-workaround.sh`
- Test results showing 100% reproducibility

[vscode-terminal-output-capture-workaround.sh](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22683680/vscode-terminal-output-capture-workaround.sh)

**File**: `TEST-PROMPTS.md` (242 lines, 6.9 KB)

### What's inside:

This file contains **3 ready-to-use test prompts** that can be copy-pasted to any AI assistant to verify the bug:

1. **PROMPT 1**: Bug verification (WITHOUT workaround)
   - Tests that the last line is consistently missing
   - 10 individual test runs
   - Designed to prevent AI automation

2. **PROMPT 2**: Workaround verification (WITH workaround script)
   - Tests that the fix works correctly
   - 10 individual test runs with the workaround loaded
   - Verifies all lines are captured

3. **PROMPT 3**: Quick comparison test
   - Shorter version for quick verification
   - 5 test runs

### Why this is useful:

- **VS Code team** can use these prompts to reproduce the bug themselves
- **Other users** can verify if they're experiencing the same issue
- **Shows methodology** behind the "100% reproducible" claim
- **Prevents false positives** by forcing manual testing (not automated loops)

### Cross-verification results using these prompts:

- ✅ GitHub Copilot (Claude 4.5): 10/10 tests confirmed bug
- ✅ Claude 4: 30/30 tests confirmed bug (multiple sessions)
- ✅ ChatGPT (GPT-5): 10/10 tests confirmed bug

All tests showed **100% failure rate without workaround** and **100% success rate with workaround**.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: GitHub Copilot Chat  v0.31.4 
- VS Code Version: 1.104.2
- OS Version: Windows 10
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent and Edit
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): All
- Logs: N/A

This is a very serious UI flaw. I have lost code about 20 times now from this one simple "feature".

1.Use copilot for the afternoon or so.
2. Don't click "keep" button
3. Press **backspace simply one too many times** in the chat window
4. window comes up that says "Delete all of the code changes from the past hour because you forgot to hit the keep button?"
5. press space bar or enter because you're in the middle of typing and you don't even see the window open.
6. cry

body:
We have quite some hard-coded "gpt-4.1" instances in our codebase 

https://github.com/search?q=repo%3Amicrosoft%2Fvscode-copilot-chat+getChatEndpoint%28%27gpt-4.1%27%29%3B&type=code

Should we have a central place where we define a default client side model? CAPI already gives us a default service side model.

Once we have a central place then `gpt-4.1` should be changed with `gpt-5-mini` (since no SKU has gpt-4.1 as default any more and we want to move as many workloads from it as possible).

@roblourens I am starting with you, as I saw quite some code areas that you own. But if you think someone else should do the cleanup feel free to assign back to me and we can find the right person.

fyi @joaomoreno

body: The `Getting Started` view is located in the chat sessions container in which `Local Chat Sessions`, `Github Copilot Coding Agent` and potentially other views are located. However, the `Getting Started` only refers to the `Github Copilot Coding Agent` view and has 2 entries. I wonder whether these 2 actions could just be incorporated into the `Github Copilot Coding Agent` view. The `Install Chat Extensions` action could show in the welcome view when no coding agent extension is available. The `Learn More About GitHub Copilot coding agent` action could be an action in the view title. This would also reduce the number of views in the `Chat Sessions` container which is nice.

- VS Code Version: 1.104.3
- OS Version: Windows 11 24H2

Steps to Reproduce:

I have a large JavaScript project (in the hundreds of thousands of lines of code) which unfortunately I cannot share. It appears that as of a fairly recent update to VS Code, every single time I open the project, a notification popups up that reads:

> To enable project-wide JavaScript/TypeScript language features, exclude large folders with source files that you do not work on.

There is a button that says 'Configure Excludes'. If I click it, it opens jsconfig.json. There inside the "exclude" key I have entered a list of five such folders that ought to be excluded. However if I close and reopen VS Code, the very same notification appears. I have nothing further to configure - I can't exclude any more folders as I work in all of them.

Have I exceeded some sort of hard limit for how large a project VS Code can handle? If so the message ought to be clearer and the limit ought to be configurable. It seems to me that the notification is appearing incorrectly, as the configuration it is asking me to perform has already been completed.

body: When it comes to showing/recommending extensions, we typically have the actions open the extensions view as this allows users to understand the extensions they are installing. Users might be more likely to install extensions from the extensions view as they see more information (like number of downloads and rating). They are also more familiar with the extensions view.

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.3 - OS Version: Windows server 2019 (WSL 1 ubuntu 22.04) This has been an issue since the releases after 1.81.1 re: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/192506 I've just recently had time to dig into this issue further and these are the findings so far. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Install vscode 2. Launch WSL shell 3. Run `code . --verbose` 4. Result is the following I then run the command that's shown when running the --verbose by copy/paste as you can see from the third arrow and code launches exactly as expected. If I `sudo su` to get to root, fix my PATH to point to the user install of code, and then run `code . --verbose` it also launches fine. The command invoked is the exact same command in every case.

Hi 👋 

I created workspace for working on multiple microservices and created various settings & extension recommendations. However, I realised `.code-workspace` don't have `snippets` options for adding snippets for that workspace only.

I think it's missing piece and low hanging fruit to make workspaces support snippets.

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: VSCode server v1.104.2, v1.104.3.
- OS Version: RHEL9.6

Description:
As an administrator user of VS Code Server, I want to configure settings.json to support noProxy and a custom extensions marketplace, so that I can bypass proxy settings for self-hosted services and point to my self-hosted marketplace registry, just as I do in VS Code Desktop.

In VSCode server, after setting the self-hosted marketplace as an environment variable, this configuration is not taken, the same applies to setting the self-hosted marketplace in product.json, which I can do in VSCode desktop. 

In addition, in VSCode server after setting the noProxy in settings.json as I do it in VSCode desktop, is not taken by VSCode server. This configuration appears in the baseEnv, but it is simply not used/not honored.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set self-hosted marketplace as environment variable or in product.json (public marketplace.visualstudio.com is not allowed).
2. Set http.proxy and noProxy in settings.json. 
3. Install an extension from your self-hosted marketplace. This attempt will fail.

I'm debugging this together with @atciocirlan

Attentive to your comments.

body:
Somewhat related to #247926.

Currently, [lm](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/references/vscode-api#lm) provides:
- `selectChatModels`, to get a list of available models.
- `onDidChangeChatModels`, for when that list changes.

Could we get similar API entries to get the _current_ model, and detect when that changes?

comments.body: The challenge is determining what you mean by "current" chat model. Each chat widget can have an independently selected model. For example, open terminal chat, inline chat, and panel chat. You have 3 separate models right there. You can even have multiple panel chats. There isn't really a "current" model

The reason why I opened this is because I want to implement logic prior to calling `workbench.action.chat.open` to figure out what model is selected in the chat that will open. Specifically, I want to have the command switch to a different model, but only if the current model is in some internal deny list. If there can be multiple panel chats, I’m not sure how to best handle this. Maybe we could allow reading the current model of whatever this command would open? Or maybe we could add a parameters to the command that is a callback for model selection, rather than a static way to set a model?

>  some internal deny list

These should just be disabled via GitHub policies then. As I assume you want to avoid users utilizing this model all up

title: Copilot not making the edits in Notebooks

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: 0.32.2025100203
- VS Code Version: 1.105.0-insider
- OS Version: MacOS 26
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): agent
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Auto
- Logs:

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In agent mode ask the copilot to make a plan for a feature
2. Copilot create the plan using Claude Sonnet 4

This happens for all tests I have done, the auto mode deciding to use Claude when both GPT-5 and GPT-Codex is enabled.

comments.body: Auto mode is not query specific but instead based on capacity. We offer a slight discount on the billing if you choose auto to incentivize you being ok with being routed to the model which we have the most GPU headroom on. You're also less likely to hit any rate limits when in auto due to the capacity headroom

The described behavior is how it is expected to work. If you disagree, please explain what is expected and what is not in more detail. See also our [issue reporting guidelines](https://aka.ms/vscodeissuereporting).

Happy Coding!
In addition to what Logan shared - we plan to make Auto task dependent in the following months - so please stay tuned.

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

title: copilot auto mode doesn't work

body:
Type: Bug I'm working in a VSC without an open folder. I wanted to generate a PowerShell script. Thanks for creating this issue! It looks like you may be using an old version of VS Code, the latest stable release is 1.104.3. Please try upgrading to the latest version and checking whether this issue remains.

Please look at the following meta issue: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252230. Please refer to that issue for updates and discussions. Feel free to open a new issue if you think this is a different problem.

I, for one, welcome, our new AI/bot overlords.

Not only did the agent/bot tool not work in a way that is obviously an edge-case bug but there's another agent/bot tool working the issue-tracker to defend that behavior and close any complaints about it. Nice.

Now, we can have a stupid response of "this happened because you were using a two-week old build, OBVS" rather than even looking at whether the submitter created the bug because it very much seems like VSC has a problem with the edge case of not having a folder open in the workspace. I would be _stunned_ to hear that this problem has been addressed in a recent version because it seems like exactly the kind of thing that would be overlooked.

The second comment, linking an issue about "billing" because I had noted that I had been billed for a query that produced no results (which, in the far, far past of perhaps a decade ago, might have been considered to be a "bug" in the "software" for which the "author" was liable but is now likely swept under the carpet of one or other EULA in which companies can publish buggy software for which they cheerily bill their customers and offer no recourse for clawing any of that money back should services rendered not even approach that which is advertised).

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No (this bug involves GitHub Copilot) - VS Code Version: 1.104.3 - OS Version: Darwin arm64 23.6.0 Full about from VS Code Version: 1.104.3 Commit: 385651c938df8a906869babee516bffd0ddb9829 Date: 2025-10-02T12:30:51.747Z (17 hrs ago) Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12404162 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Darwin arm64 23.6.0 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Select Agent mode, prompt "run `which ls` and then `ls` in terminal". 2. Approve the requests to run commands in terminal 3. See the error. Additional observations: 1. This doesn't reproduce in manually created terminals. It reproduces in terminals created by Copilot. 2. This doesn't reproduce in the my latest Insider VS Code. 3. I was using earlier 1.104 stable versions and I don't recall seeing this issue. The error looks similar to the errors in this issue but that's a very old one. https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/124409

Type: Bug ## Reproduction 1. Open [demo](https://codesandbox.io/p/devbox/y9vsrr?file=%2Ftest.js%3A3%2C5). 2. Go to `test.js` file. 3. Open `foo`'s Parameter Hints. #### Actual #### Expected (see `index.d.ts`) ## Description When a function's JSDoc comments in a declaration file include `@overload` or `@template` tags, the Parameter Hints for that function do not properly display function's and parameter's information such as current parameter's description or function's returned value description. If in the provided demo, the `@overload` and `@template` tags are removed from `index.d.ts`, `foo`'s Parameter Hints will correctly display expected information. ### Additional context Some JS projects use JSDoc for type annotations and use TypeScript [only to generate declaration files](https://www.typescriptlang.org/tsconfig/#emitDeclarationOnly). Thank you for your patience and understanding.

title: wrong languege

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
### Description

The current `editor.aiStats.enabled` setting is a boolean that only allows enabling/disabling AI statistics in the status bar. This limits its usefulness for users who might want to see other types of statistics, such as their GitHub Copilot Premium quota usage.

### Proposed Solution

Refactor the AI Stats feature into a more general **Stats** feature with multiple display modes:

1. **Rename the setting**: `editor.aiStats.enabled` → `editor.stats.enabled`
2. **Change from boolean to enum** with three options:
   - `'off'` - Do not show statistics in the status bar
   - `'aiStats'` - Show AI vs manual typing statistics (current functionality)
   - `'premiumQuota'` - Show GitHub Copilot Premium request quota usage

### Benefits

- **More flexible**: Users can choose what statistics matter most to them
- **Better resource awareness**: Premium users can monitor their quota usage at a glance
- **Extensible**: Easy to add more stat types in the future
- **Maintains backward compatibility**: Defaults to `'aiStats'` mode

### Implementation Details

The status bar gauge would adapt based on the selected mode:

**AI Stats Mode** (`'aiStats'`):
- Shows percentage of AI-generated code vs manually typed code over 24 hours
- Hover displays: AI vs Typing Average and accepted inline suggestions count

**Premium Quota Mode** (`'premiumQuota'`):
- Shows percentage of GitHub Copilot Premium quota used
- Hover displays: Premium requests used (e.g., "50% (100 of 200)")
- Handles unlimited quota gracefully

**Off Mode** (`'off'`):
- Status bar gauge is hidden
- Feature completely disabled

### Example Usage

```json
{
  "editor.stats.enabled": "premiumQuota"
}
```

### Technical Changes

- Rename `AiStatsFeature` → `StatsFeature`
- Rename `AiStatsStatusBar` → `StatsStatusBar`
- Add integration with `IChatEntitlementService` for quota data
- Update configuration schema to support enum values
- Maintain all existing AI stats functionality

### Screenshots/Mockups

The visual appearance would remain the same - a small gauge in the status bar - but the percentage and tooltip content would change based on the selected mode.

---

**Additional Context**

This change would be particularly useful for GitHub Copilot Premium users who want to keep track of their monthly request quota without opening the Copilot status panel.

comments.body: /feature

Please look at the following meta issue: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/252230. Please refer to that issue for updates and discussions. Feel free to open a new issue if you think this is a different problem.

title: Refactor AI Stats to general Stats feature with multiple display modes

body:
> # VS Code Architecture Conflict on x86_64 architecture - Proposed Solution
> 
> ## Summary
> VS Code fails to start on Intel Mac due to ARM64 binaries in microsoft-authentication extension being loaded on x86_64 architecture.
> 
> ## Environment
> - **OS**: macOS (Intel Mac x86_64)
> - **VS Code Version**: 1.104.2
> - **Architecture**: x86_64
> - **Affected Extension**: microsoft-authentication (built-in)
> 
> ## Problem Description
> VS Code attempts to load ARM64 native binaries on Intel Mac, causing:
> - `Bad CPU type in executable` errors
> - Extension host crashes
> - MCP bridge connection failures
> - Requires `arch -x86_64` workaround
> 
> ## Symptoms
> - MCP bridge intermittent disconnects
> - Developer Console logs:
> ERR [Extension Host] Failed to load MSAL binary: Error: dlopen(/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/msal-node-runtime.node, 0x0001): tried: '/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/msal-node-runtime.node' (mach-o file, but is an incompatible architecture (have 'arm64', need 'x86_64h' or 'x86_64')), '/System/Volumes/Preboot/Cryptexes/OS/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/msal-node-runtime.node' (no such file), '/Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/msal-node-runtime.node' (mach-o file, but is an incompatible architecture (have 'arm64', need 'x86_64h' or 'x86_64'))
> 
> ## Root Cause Analysis
> The `@azure/msal-node-runtime` npm package (v0.19.5) only ships ARM64 binaries for macOS:
> ```
> package/dist/macos/arm64/libmsalruntime.dylib  (ARM64)
> package/dist/macos/arm64/msal-node-runtime.node (ARM64)
> ```
> 
> Windows gets both x86 and x64, but macOS only gets ARM64.
> 
> ## Files Affected
> ```
> /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/msal-node-runtime.node
> /Applications/Visual Studio Code.app/Contents/Resources/app/extensions/microsoft-authentication/dist/libmsalruntime.dylib
> ```
> 
> ## Reproduction Steps
> 1. Install VS Code on Intel Mac
> 2. Launch VS Code
> 3. Observe extension host failures in Developer Tools Console
> 4. MCP integrations fail to connect
> 
> ## Expected Behavior
> VS Code should start normally on Intel Mac without architecture conflicts.
> 
> ## Actual Behavior
> Architecture mismatch causes extension loading failures and requires x86_64 emulation workaround.
> 
> ## Resolution Attempts
> - Complete removal and reinstallation of Visual Studio Code
> - Complete removal and reinstallation of all extensions
> - Update nvm dependencies via Terminal
> - Launch Visual Studio Code using x86_64 specification in Terminal:
> ```
> arch -x86_64 open -a "Visual Studio Code"
> ```
> 
> ## Suggested Fix
> 1. Update `@azure/msal-node-runtime` to ship x64 binaries for macOS
> 2. Or implement fallback logic in extension when native binaries are incompatible
> 3. Or disable native broker on incompatible architectures
> 
> ## Temporary Workaround
> Replace ARM64 binaries with x64 stubs (functional but disables native auth broker).
> 
> ## Impact
> - Affects all Intel Mac users
> - Prevents proper extension host operation
> - Breaks MCP protocol integrations
> - Forces users to use x86_64 emulation mode
> 
> ## Additional Technical Details
> 
> ### VS Code Extension Analysis
> - Extension: `extensions/microsoft-authentication`
> - Package: `@azure/msal-node-runtime@0.19.5`
> - Issue: ARM64-only distribution for macOS
> - Impact: Intel Mac compatibility broken
> 
> ### copyBinaries.js Analysis
> The package's install script correctly looks for platform/arch:
> ```javascript
> var arch = process.arch == "ia32" ? "x86" : process.arch; // x64
> var platform = platformMapping[process.platform]; // macos  
> var sourceDir = path.join(__dirname, "dist", platform, arch); // dist/macos/x64
> ```
> 
> But `dist/macos/x64/` doesn't exist - only `dist/macos/arm64/` exists.
> 
> ### Microsoft Should Fix
> 1. **@azure/msal-node-runtime**: Ship x64 binaries for macOS
> 2. **VS Code build**: Add architecture validation  
> 3. **Extension**: Graceful fallback when native binaries unavailable
> 
> ### Our Workaround Proves Fix is Simple
> Replacing ARM64 binaries with x64 stubs completely resolves the issue.
>  

 _Originally posted by @space-japan-studios in [#265424](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/265424#issuecomment-3359725701)_

body:
Currently, the Global: Auto Approve setting for Copilot Chat tools in VS Code applies to all tools, and does not support per-tool or per-extension granularity. This limits flexibility for users and organizations who may want to auto-approve only a subset of trusted tools, while requiring manual approval for others.

**Feature Request:**
- Add a setting to allow users to specify which tools are auto-approved, rather than applying the setting globally to all tools.
- This could be a list of tool names, extension IDs, or FastMCP tool identifiers.
- Enable organization policy to manage granular approval for environments where security and compliance are important.
- Ideally, the UI should provide an easy way to manage these settings and review which tools have auto-approval enabled.

**Motivation:**
- Improves security and control, especially in enterprise environments.
- Lets users streamline their workflow for trusted tools while retaining manual approval for others.
- Aligns with best practices for permissions management in extensible systems.

**References:**
- [VS Code Chat Tools Settings](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/copilot/chat#_tool-approval)
- [GitHub Copilot Chat Extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.copilot-chat)

Thank you for considering this feature!

comments.body: @Tyriar what do you think?

@digitarald has brought up an ask that enterprises want a more unified way of managing auto approve. Moving everything into settings would be great, we just need a nice setting/format that works for all the different tool kinds. While at the same time allow tools to have special formats for more fine grained control (terminal, edit tools, etc.)

body:
# Custom Chat Modes Cannot Use Tool Groups - Must Explicitly List Individual Tools

## Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?
Yes (This is a core VS Code / GitHub Copilot Chat feature)

## Environment
- **VS Code Version:** 1.104.3
- **OS Version:** Windows 11
- **GitHub Copilot Extension Version:** Latest
- **Affected Feature:** Custom Chat Modes (`.chatmode.md` files)
VSCODE:
Version: 1.104.3 (user setup)
Commit: 385651c938df8a906869babee516bffd0ddb9829
Date: 2025-10-02T12:30:51.747Z
Electron: 37.3.1
ElectronBuildId: 12404162
Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
Node.js: 22.18.0
V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26200

GitHub Copilot Extension:
Installation
Identifier
github.copilot
Version
1.372.0
Last Updated
2025-09-22, 18:44:51
Size
68.22MB
Marketplace
Published
2021-06-29, 09:26:17
Last Released
2025-09-26, 10:30:55

## Issue Summary
When defining tools in custom chat mode YAML frontmatter, **tool group names** (like `runCommands`, `microsoftdocs/mcp`) are recognized and appear in the VS Code UI as valid tools, but the AI agent **cannot invoke any of the child tools** within those groups. The agent must have **individual tool names explicitly listed** for them to be callable.

## Steps to Reproduce

### Example 1: MCP Server Tool Groups

1. Create a custom chat mode file at `.github/chatmodes/test.chatmode.md`
2. Add YAML frontmatter with MCP server group name:
```yaml
---
description: 'Test mode'
tools: ['microsoftdocs/mcp']
---
```
3. Activate the chat mode in GitHub Copilot Chat
4. Observe: VS Code UI shows "MCP Server: microsoftdocs/mcp" as enabled ✅
5. Ask the AI to search Microsoft documentation
6. **Result:** AI fails to call `microsoft_docs_search`, `microsoft_docs_fetch`, or `microsoft_code_sample_search` tools

**Workaround:** Explicitly list individual tools:
```yaml
---
description: 'Test mode'
tools: ['microsoft_docs_search', 'microsoft_docs_fetch', 'microsoft_code_sample_search']
---
```
**Result:** AI can now successfully call all three tools ✅

---

### Example 2: Terminal Command Tool Groups

1. Create a custom chat mode file
2. Add YAML frontmatter with terminal group name:
```yaml
---
description: 'Test mode'
tools: ['runCommands']
---
```
3. Activate the chat mode
4. Observe: UI shows tool group as enabled
5. Ask the AI to run a terminal command
6. **Result:** AI fails with error: `Tool run_in_terminal is currently disabled by the user`

**Workaround:** Explicitly list individual terminal tools:
```yaml
---
description: 'Test mode'
tools: ['getTerminalOutput', 'terminalSelection', 'terminalLastCommand', 'runInTerminal']
---
```
**Result:** AI can now successfully execute terminal commands ✅

---

## Expected Behavior
When a tool group name (like `runCommands` or `microsoftdocs/mcp`) is specified in the `tools` array, the chat mode should have access to **all child tools** within that group, just as it does when those tools are individually listed.

## Actual Behavior
- Tool groups are **recognized by VS Code** (appear in UI with checkmarks)
- Tool groups are **not accessible to the AI agent** at runtime
- AI receives errors stating tools are "disabled" or simply doesn't attempt to call them
- Only **explicitly listed individual tool names** are callable by the AI

## Impact
This bug requires users to:
1. Manually discover and list every individual tool name (not documented clearly)
2. Maintain verbose tool lists instead of using convenient group names
3. Update chat modes whenever tool groups add new tools
4. Deal with unclear error messages about "disabled" tools that are actually enabled

## Additional Context

**Affected Tool Groups Confirmed:**
- `runCommands` → Contains: `getTerminalOutput`, `terminalSelection`, `terminalLastCommand`, `runInTerminal`
- `microsoftdocs/mcp` → Contains: `microsoft_docs_search`, `microsoft_docs_fetch`, `microsoft_code_sample_search`
- Likely affects: `azure` MCP server and other MCP tool groups

## Related Configuration Files
- `mcp.json` location: `%APPDATA%\Code\User\mcp.json`
- Chat mode files location: `.github/chatmodes/*.chatmode.md`

## Suggested Fix
When a tool group name is specified in the `tools` array, the runtime should **automatically expand** that group to include all child tool names, making them available to the AI agent just as if they were individually listed.

Alternatively, update the VS Code UI to **not show tool groups as "enabled"** if they won't actually grant access to their child tools, to avoid confusion.

body:
> im facing a very similar issue. my /mcp implementation returns a WWW-Authenticate header in response to a 401 on the /mcp address.
> ```
> OnChallenge = context =>
> {
>     var prmUrl = $"{serverUrl}/.well-known/oauth-protected-resource";
>     // Prevent redirect/challenge - just return 401
>     context.HandleResponse();
>     context.Response.StatusCode = StatusCodes.Status401Unauthorized;
>     context.Response.Headers.Append("WWW-Authenticate", $"Bearer realm=\"MCP\", resource_metadata=\"{prmUrl}\"");
>     return context.Response.WriteAsync("Unauthorized");
> }
> ```
> the .well-known endpoint returns the correct info in the setup of resourcedata including the correct auth servers but vscode just uses the `{serverUrl}` as its base address to make the authorize call on. In my case localhost:8081/authorize
> 
> the flow all seems to work, except not adhering to the returned `authorization_servers`
> 
> resource response:
> ```
> {
>     "resource": "https://localhost:8081/mcp",
>     "authorization_servers": [
>         "https://my-auth-server/auth"
>     ],
>     "bearer_methods_supported": [
>         "header"
>     ],
>     "scopes_supported": [
>         "<the-scope>",
>     ],
>     "resource_documentation": "https://docs.my-mcp.com"
> }
> ```
> 
> https://modelcontextprotocol.io/specification/draft/basic/authorization#authorization-flow-steps
> the spec and the diagram provided suggests it should be parsing the metadata and extracting the authorization servers 

 _Originally posted by @wolfpackt99 in [#268880](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268880#issuecomment-3362007771)_
