body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
I have to work with my C++ project on both Windows and Linux. So far the only problem with it that I have is debugging options. I'm debugging it at once on both systems (remotely, in separate VS Code windows connected to vscode server through SSH) and I keep confusing what system I'm currently debuging and I'm clicking on wrong launch option. Currently there's no way for me to stop this from happening. I can't even create a shared debug profile that will satisfy my requirements for both systems, I have to use specific one for each system. The `linux` and `windows` blocks inside launch configuration didn't really help much since you can't use `type` parameter inside any of those blocks, hence I can't specify `cppvsdbg` type for Windows and `cppdbg` for Linux. What I'm trying to say is, it would be nice to have optional global parameter for every launch type to hide it from the list on specific system. Something like:

```json
    {
      "name": "(Windows) Launch",
      "type": "cppvsdbg",
      "request": "launch",
      "program": "${workspaceRoot}/_build/_Install/app.exe",
      "args": [],
      "stopAtEntry": false,
      "hideOn": ["osx", "linux"], // <---- here it is
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}/_build/_Install",
      "environment": [],
      "console": "integratedTerminal"
    },
```

Thanks for reporting this issue! Unfortunately, it's hard for us to understand what issue you're seeing. Please help us out by providing a screen recording showing exactly what isn't working as expected. While we can work with most standard formats, `.gif` files are preferred as they are displayed inline on GitHub. You may find https://gifcap.dev helpful as a browser-based gif recording tool.

If the issue depends on keyboard input, you can help us by enabling screencast mode for the recording (`Developer: Toggle Screencast Mode` in the command palette). Lastly, please attach this file via the GitHub web interface as emailed responses will strip files out from the issue.

Happy coding!

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
As noted in the title, it would be nice if the "move line up/down" commands didn't move lines with only the trailing newline character selected. This would make the feature play a lot nicer with "Duplicate selection":
The desired workflow is as follows: I want to duplicate some lines and move them somewhere else. So "Select range" > "Duplicate selection" > "Move line down/up". The problem is that I need to select the newline on the line before for duplicate to work, otherwise this happens:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/52b07ffa-a793-4e62-9761-61353c2370ce)

Now, if I select the newline before:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/1019e0e8-0063-49a5-a9ce-995d7a64879a)
Here, the duplication works as expected, but moving the lines now moves the previous line too (line 6), which is not what I want.

body: [Default account](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7680230b2fe0f603a3a6a911a2805e171799484c/src/vs/workbench/services/accounts/common/defaultAccount.ts#L128) and [chat entitlement](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/7680230b2fe0f603a3a6a911a2805e171799484c/src/vs/workbench/services/chat/common/chatEntitlementService.ts#L219) share similar authentication and entitlement strategies. Default account is used for policies and private marketplace where chat entitlement is used for AI login. Default account is lagging behind chat entitlement. We should merge these two so that there is just one source of truth.

body:
### GitHub Tags:
#A11yTCS; #A11ySev2; #DesktopApp; #Win11; #Win32; #A11yMAS; #SH-Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions-Win32-Sept25;#Visual Studio Code Client;#WCAG2.1.1; #Keyboard;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions
Visual studio code Version: 1.104.2 (user setup)
Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 Build 26100.6584

### Repro Steps:

1. Open Visual studio Code.
2. Login to GitHub copilot chat.
3. Tab till GitHub copilot chat section.
4. Tab till Select tools button and press enter.
5. Select tools pane will get open. Tab till longer tool name.
6. Observe that Customize tooltip is defined for the "Select tools" name where the information is longer in "Select tools" panel and keyboard accessible or not.

### Actual Result:
Tooltip is defined as title attribute and tooltip is not accessible via keyboard navigation for the "Select tools" name where the information is longer in "Select tools" panel.

### Expected Result:
Customize tooltip should be defined for the "Select tools" name where the information is longer in "Select tools" panel and should be keyboard accessible.

### User Impact:
Keyboard-only users cannot access critical information conveyed in the tooltip, leading to confusion or missed functionality

### Attachment:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a8146bf5-17cc-46a7-a3ed-373c63e50693

comments.body: @TylerLeonhardt has there been any history / accessibility work on this quick pick feature ?

This has never happened for the quick pick, even if the file picker: It's read out by the screen reader, but hover is not shown when it has focus... but if hover showed when it had focus, that'd cover up the other row... so I'm not sure that'd even look nice.
Using `ctrlCmd+k+i` on the item shows the longer information for me

body: ### GitHub Tags: #A11yTCS; #A11ySev2; #DesktopApp; #Win32; #A11yMAS; #SH-Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions-Win32-Sept25;#Visual Studio Code Client;#WCAG4.3.1; #No Disruption of Accessibility Features; ### Environment Details: Application Name: Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions Visual studio code Version: 1.104.2 (user setup) Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 Build 26100.6584 ### Repro Steps: 1. Turn on VS Code dark theme. 2. Open Visual studio Code. 3. Login to GitHub copilot chat. 4. Tab till github copilot chat section. 5. Tab till code editor section and press "Ctrl+i" inline copilot chat will get open. 6. Enter the prompt and send it. 7. Solution will appear in editor section. 8. Observe that In Dark theme, the contrast ratio of pink color text in the editor section is greater than or equal to 4.5:1 or not. ### Actual Result: In Dark theme, the contrast ratio of pink text in the editor section is 2.482:1, which is below the required minimum of 4.5:1. ### Expected Result: In Dark theme, the contrast ratio of pink text in the editor section with respect to its background should be greater than or equal to required 4.5:1. ### User Impact: low vision and visually impaired users will face difficulty in viewing the text if the color contrast ratio of text is less than required 4.5:1 with respect to its background ### Attachment:

comments.body: We should meet at least 3 for this case - as it's not normal text, it is being used in a UI component.
Low vision and visually impaired users can make use of our high contrast themes if they need 4.5 contrast for this component.

Can you follow these steps so that we can get more information on what's going on?

#### Enable trace logging

* Open the Command Palette (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Trace`, click the *double* check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (enables trace logging as the default)

_Now wait for the issue to happen or trigger it..._

#### Getting the logs

* Open the Command Palette again (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Output: Show Output Channels...` command
* Choose `GitHub Authentication`
* Copy and paste the contents of what opens in the panel in this issue (if the contents is too large, you may need to upload it as a file)

Do these steps again for these other output channels:
* `GitHub Copilot Chat`
* `GitHub Copilot`
* `window` <- this one is important

#### Reverting trace logging (optional)

When we're done here, to revert the log level back to the default:
* Open the Command Palette
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Info`, click the double check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (to set the default back to info)
Cc @bpasero

Can you rename it in Windows Explorer?

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.2
- OS Version: Linux x64 6.16.8-arch3-1

### Moving multiple lines by placing a cursor on lines that are adjacent fails to move those lines 

Moving multiple lines without selecting text only works if the lines that contain a cursor are not adjacent to each other. For example, if I have a cursor in line 1 and line 3, I can move both of those lines — but I select lines 1,2, and 3, then I can only move line 1. Furthermore, if I select line 1, line 3, and then line 2, then I can only move line 1 and 3. 

Setting Multi Cursor Merge Overlapping to either True or False does not fix the issue.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. create a text file. 
2. create 10 lines, for line 1, type the number "1", line 2, type "2", etc.
3. place a cursor at the beginning of line 1
4. press alt + shift + down five times to create 5 additional cursors below it. there should be a cursor at the start of lines 1 - 5.
5. press alt + down two times to move lines 1 - 5 down twice. 
6. expected behavior: all 5 lines move. actual behavior: only line 1 moves.
- expected output:
```
6
1
2
3
4
5
7
8
9
10
```
- actual output:
```
2
1
3
4
5
6
7
8
9
10
```
title: moving multiple lines by placing a cursor on lines that are adjacent fails to move those lines

body:
Type: Performance Issue I have Copilot enabled, and when I type, I can quickly get 3 or 4 words ahead of what I see on the screen. VS Code is unusable, going back to GVim. My PL/SQL file is 30,000 lines long, which appears to be slowing it down. It would be a lot of work to try to split this into multiple packages. Is there a recommended max file size that Copilot can handle? I tried disabling every extension one by one, but it didn't help. Even with all extensions disabled VS Code was still very slow. When I shut down VS Code and open it with only a few small files, it performs fine, no issues. It only seems to be a problem when I have this large file open. VS Code version: Code 1.104.2 (e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92, 2025-09-24T11:21:37.073Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

body: I had this persistent status bar item show up, I'm guessing it's related to JSON schema as I had settings.json open at the time. - Clicking it would show a stopwatch icon for a few ms before switching back to the warning icon. - I looked for useful logs in output channels but couldn't find any. - I am on an internet connection that drops occasionally, but I am clicking it now when the internet is active and working fine. - I'm in Korea in case this is a geo issue. - This is only happening in Code - OSS, not insiders ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/fb7fe7cf-bdff-41e9-bcbf-abc5e885ea01)

comments.body: After I fixed copilot chat sign in problems (adding more enabled APIs) the problem seems to have gone away. It would be good to get some feedback that hints at why the request failed and maybe more detail about what schema it is talking about.

This can happen if we fail to load a schema due to lack of an internet connection.
It would be interesting to know what http schema is referred to by our settings schema. 

The JSON file would should squiggles on the schema reference (or top level element) with that info

body: How rules normally look: When the `Select-` prefix regex is referenced it breaks the wrapping `_` to style it with italics though: Code reference: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/6e60e679fc6b6a512edbed9a750d7c5811595861/src/vs/workbench/contrib/terminalContrib/chatAgentTools/browser/tools/runInTerminalTool.ts#L865-L901

comments.body:
What steps can I take to repo this?

Also instead of using markdown to add the italic, can you add it with css?
Ask to run Select-Object should repro it. I could do italics in css, would be good to fix the root cause though.

Thanks. Opened upstream marked issue: https://github.com/markedjs/marked/issues/3774

Can be fixed by using `*` instead of `_` for the italics, but I'd recommend using css for the italics if possible
Not so easy to use CSS here unfortunately since this is a generic markdown string we pass to somewhere else. Moved to asterisk as the easy fix for now.
Will close this out with https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/269646

Expose lines numbers so that Windows 11 Voice access is able to see them for navigation.

comments.body:
Can you follow these steps so that we can get more information on what's going on?

#### Enable trace logging

* Open the Command Palette (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Trace`, click the *double* check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (enables trace logging as the default)

_Now wait for the issue to happen or trigger it..._

#### Getting the logs

* Open the Command Palette again (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Output: Show Output Channels...` command
* Choose `GitHub Authentication`
* Copy and paste the contents of what opens in the panel in this issue (if the contents is too large, you may need to upload it as a file)

Do these steps again for these other output channels:
* `GitHub Copilot Chat`
* `GitHub Copilot`
* `window` <- very important 

#### Reverting trace logging (optional)

When we're done here, to revert the log level back to the default:
* Open the Command Palette
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Info`, click the double check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (to set the default back to info)
Cc @bpasero

body: Testing #268926 I ran the following command, which should take exactly 5 seconds to run `.vscode/tasks.json`: ```json { "version": "2.0.0", "tasks": [ { "label": "Run for 5 seconds", "type": "shell", "command": "sleep 5 && echo 'Task completed after 5 seconds'", "group": "build" } ] } ``` However, the notification on Windows says that the task took 7 seconds. Is this a performance issue? Or an issue with the computation of the run duration?

comments.body: Think it's just rounding up and how long the code took to process the start of the task then the execution
Sidenote: Mac seems to consistently say it finished in 5 seconds: And Windows seems to consistently say it finished in 7 seconds 🤷
Classic Windows slowness 😆

```
Tool copilot_searchCodebase completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed. code blocks: 3

Orca acts weird sometimes and it's not in our control. Since it works as expected with NVDA and VoiceOver, closing this

Actually, what was your focus on when you heard this from the screen reader? 🤔 

Based on your screenshot, looks like general `Chat` panel?
My focus was Copilot response. when I was trying to take the screenshot it shifted.

Should this part be there in the aria-label value:
Tool copilot_searchCodebase completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed.Tool copilot_findFiles completed.Tool copilot_readFile completed

Ah, I see. Thanks for the issue. I can actually repro on macOS with VoiceOver. we added this info to indicate tool status to screen reader users, but now, since we indicate verbose progress, can remove that.
It looks correct now:

V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 6.8.0-85-generic

I've also noticed particularly slow scrolling, although not tied specifically to the trackpad.

Using all default mouse/scroll settings.

Scrolling in the integrated terminal, with my mouse wheel, jumps 2 lines for standard output, and 1 line for paged cli applications like `man`. However, scrolling in my default system terminal `gnome-terminal`, jumps 4 lines for both.

1 and 2 lines each IS a touch slow, but I'm less concerned with the fact that the scroll multiplier/sensitivity does not match my default terminal's settings, and instead that the integrated terminal does not appear to be self consistent between paged and non-paged modes.

I'm not super familiar with scrolling implementations, so it could be the case that my observed 1 vs 2 lines is just the product of rounding the final deltas (either done by VSCode or the pager application itself). Either way, something feels off.

body:
Testing #268983 This isn't something that was asked for, and it was placed _at the root_ of the repo after making a large (relative to the brand new codebase) contribution. It also modified README.md, which IMO is fine. But adding a new file has other implications (maintenance and whatnot), that I did not want to introduce. # Contents of IMPLEMENTATION.md # Implementation Details: Dungeon View Panel ## Overview This document describes the implementation of the dropdown webview panel under the VS Code Explorer sidebar. ## Architecture ``` ┌─────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ VS Code Explorer Sidebar │ ├─────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ 📁 File Explorer │ │ 📂 Open Editors │ │ 📂 Outline │ ├─────────────────────────────────────────┤ │ 🏰 Dungeon View Panel (Collapsible) │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ Webview Content Area │ │ │ │ - HTML/CSS/JavaScript │ │ │ │ - Placeholder for Mermaid │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────┘ ``` ## Components ### 1. Package.json Configuration The `package.json` file declares the view contribution: ```json "contributes": { "views": { "explorer": [ { "type": "webview", "id": "code-dungeon.dungeonView", "name": "Dungeon View" } ] } } ``` **Key Points:** - `type: "webview"` - Indicates this is a webview-based view - `id` - Unique identifier used to register the provider - `name` - Display name shown in the UI - `explorer` container - Places the view in the Explorer sidebar ### 2. DungeonViewProvider Class Located in `src/web/extension.ts`, this class implements the `WebviewViewProvider` interface: ```typescript class DungeonViewProvider implements vscode.WebviewViewProvider { public static readonly viewType = 'code-dungeon.dungeonView'; resolveWebviewView( webviewView: vscode.WebviewView, context: vscode.WebviewViewResolveContext, _token: vscode.CancellationToken ) { // Configure webview options webviewView.webview.options = { enableScripts: true, // Required for Mermaid localResourceRoots: [this._extensionUri] }; // Set HTML content webviewView.webview.html = this._getHtmlForWebview(webviewView.webview); } } ``` **Key Points:** - `enableScripts: true` - Enables JavaScript execution for future Mermaid integration - `localResourceRoots` - Security setting for loading local resources - HTML generation is separated into `_getHtmlForWebview` method for maintainability ### 3. Webview HTML Content The HTML uses VS Code's theme CSS variables for seamless integration: ```css body { padding: 10px; color: var(--vscode-foreground); background-color: var(--vscode-editor-background); font-family: var(--vscode-font-family); } ``` **Theme Variables Used:** - `--vscode-foreground` - Text color - `--vscode-editor-background` - Background color - `--vscode-font-family` - Font family - `--vscode-panel-border` - Border color This ensures the panel respects user theme preferences (dark/light modes). ### 4. Extension Activation The provider is registered in the `activate` function: ```typescript export function activate(context: vscode.ExtensionContext) { const provider = new DungeonViewProvider(context.extensionUri); context.subscriptions.push( vscode.window.registerWebviewViewProvider( DungeonViewProvider.viewType, provider ) ); } ``` **Key Points:** - Provider instance is created with extension URI for resource loading - Registration is added to subscriptions for proper cleanup - View type ID must match the ID in package.json ## Future Enhancements ### Mermaid Diagram Integration To add Mermaid diagram rendering: 1. Add Mermaid library to the HTML: ```html ``` 2. Add diagram container: ```html
graph TD A[Code] --> B[Dungeon]
``` 3. Initialize Mermaid: ```javascript mermaid.initialize({ startOnLoad: true }); ``` ### Message Passing To enable communication between extension and webview: ```typescript // In extension webviewView.webview.onDidReceiveMessage(message => { // Handle messages from webview }); webviewView.webview.postMessage({ type: 'update', data: ... }); ``` ```javascript // In webview const vscode = acquireVsCodeApi(); vscode.postMessage({ type: 'request', data: ... }); window.addEventListener('message', event => { const message = event.data; // Handle messages from extension }); ``` ## Testing The implementation includes a basic test to verify extension activation: ```typescript test('Extension should be activated', async () => { const ext = vscode.extensions.getExtension('undefined_publisher.code-dungeon'); assert.ok(ext); await ext?.activate(); assert.strictEqual(ext?.isActive, true); }); ``` ## Build and Development ### Commands - `npm run compile-web` - Build for development - `npm run watch-web` - Watch mode for auto-rebuild - `npm run package-web` - Production build - `npm run lint` - Run ESLint - `npm test` - Run tests ### File Structure ``` code-dungeon/ ├── src/web/ │ ├── extension.ts # Main extension code │ └── test/suite/ │ ├── index.ts # Test runner │ └── extension.test.ts # Test cases ├── dist/web/ │ └── extension.js # Built extension (gitignored) ├── package.json # Extension manifest └── webpack.config.js # Build configuration ``` ## Browser Compatibility This is a **web extension** that runs in a webworker context: - No Node.js APIs available - Uses browser-compatible APIs only - Webpack bundles everything into a single file - Compatible with VS Code for the Web (vscode.dev) # Chat History: ME: I want my extension to insert a drop down panel under the fule explorer / timeline / outline views. I want this to be a webview that will eventually render dynamically generated mermaid diagrams, but it should only display the most minimal implementation that can be built upon after. How can I do this? I'll help you create a minimal dropdown panel under the file explorer views using VS Code's webview API. Let me first examine the current extension structure to understand how to integrate this properly. Searched text for package.json (**/package.json), no results Let me search for the [package.json](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html) file: Now I have a good understanding of your VS Code web extension project. To create a minimal dropdown panel under the file explorer views, you'll need to: Register a custom view in the explorer sidebar Create a webview panel that can eventually render Mermaid diagrams Update the [package.json](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html) to declare the view Implement the view provider in your extension Here's the minimal implementation: 1. Update [package.json](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html) First, you need to declare the custom view in your [package.json](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html): 2. Update [extension.ts](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html) Replace your [src/web/extension.ts](vscode-file://vscode-app/c:/Users/bevillal/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft%20VS%20Code%20Insiders/resources/app/out/vs/code/electron-browser/workbench/workbench.html) with this minimal implementation: 3. Build and Test Now you can build and test your extension: Build the extension: Test the extension: Press F5 to launch the "Run Web Extension" In the new VS Code window, look at the Explorer sidebar You should see a new "Code Dungeon" panel at the bottom Click the "Generate Sample Diagram" button to test the interaction What This Implementation Provides ✅ Minimal webview panel in the Explorer sidebar ✅ Proper VS Code theming using CSS variables ✅ Bidirectional communication between extension and webview ✅ Sample diagram generation with placeholder for Mermaid ✅ Web extension compatible (no Node.js dependencies) Next Steps for Mermaid Integration When you're ready to add actual Mermaid diagram rendering, you'll need to: Include Mermaid library in your webview HTML (via CDN for web extension compatibility) Replace the text display with actual Mermaid rendering Add dynamic content generation based on workspace analysis Handle diagram interactions and navigation This foundation gives you a working panel that you can iteratively enhance with more sophisticated diagram generation and rendering capabilities. ME: Great! Please implement

body: Testing #268985 In the example below, the tool call shows that the agent started to work on task 4 out of 8 while the todo list widget shows that 3 out of 8 are done as well as the title of the 4th task. However, intuitively I read this similar to the tool call progress, i.e. "the 3rd task, Rewrite line sanitizer tests, out of 8 tasks is in progress" which is wrong. I propose to adopt the tool call message convention, i.e. talk about the 4th out of 8 tasks.
title: Cofusing labeling between todo list tool calls and todo list

body:
Testing #268985

While the agent is active I can clear the todo list. Since the todo list is a tool for the agent, we should consider disabling the action while the agent is active.
title: Disabled Clear Todo List during a run

body: Testing #268985 The agent response, aka chat output, and the todo list blend together. This leads to the perception that the view shows screen cheese and it's hard to spot the list if I'm interested in it. I propose to use the same background color as the changed file list and use borders to separate the todo list from the changed file list.
title: Let the todo list visually stand out more

Testing #268697

As each line of thought appeared, it'd flicker quickly to expand and then change to the appropriate summary title (I attempted to move my cursor toward these instances in the gif). Toward the end, the reading action was also a bit cutoff.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4e75420d-bfee-46fb-9ca6-0a880259dc2c)

comments.body:
I realize this may just be a codex problem. With GPT-5, the `fixedScrolling` rendering looks much better:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/17e240ee-a77a-436b-97cb-b9f6708b103f)

yeah this is codex specifically with this style of thinking since it will auto-collapse once thinking is done! as you mentioned, it looks good in gpt-5 since it actually streams text, but not that great in codex :( i've been brainstorming some things and i think the best way to ensure a good experience in each model is just to have different styles for each model

body: Testing #268697 with `thinkingStyle` as `collapsed` Maybe could be counted as part of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/269131, given it has to do with codex rendering. The UI here feels a bit overwhelming: - `Configuring a Python Environment` is larger font, more indented, and has a border - I suppose I expected it to be a built-in / behind-the-scenes part of `Using "Select a Python Environment"` rather than its own separate, larger thing that steals my focus - I expected more chat output before a large pwsh command code block - After asking the model to think really hard, I expected either more expandable thinking entries, or more direct chat output (though I now realize that probably wouldn't be the case, since I set `collapsed`)

comments.body:
I think this item from the TPI description captures at least part of what I expected:

> There were initial mock ups to hide specific tool calls (ie, searches, reads, list dirs, and more) and group them with thinking in the dropdown, but that will be tabled since there is so much variance in Codex vs. GPT-5.

i agree, although ion this case with the `collpased`, it's probably the _least_ overwhelming of the options haha. i have some ideas on how to make this ui cleaner by balancing it out with each of the other UIs and following those more closely

title: Thinking in Codex results in multiple font sizes and levels of indentation

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->

Is there a possibility to add a configuration option to always clear the chat when changing the mode? And not display the popup. Maybe there is already one?

comments.body: You probably only see this when switching to Edit mode, and you can avoid that by setting `"chat.edits2.enabled": true`, I wonder whether that works for you? The downside is that this uses a version of Edit mode based on Agent mode, and some models that we don't have tool support for will not work.
Thank you for your reply. It works for me indeed.

body:
Testing #268923

Repros using Windows + Insiders + Narrator

Repro steps:
1. Open the chat panel and issue a request (or open an existing chat)
2. Start Narrator and enable SR optimized mode
3. Repeatedly edit (either via mouse or keyboard) and press Esc on a request until VS Code crashes:
  ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/814c03ae-f297-467f-9ec0-9019d8f9e8d3)

comments.body: Repros in stable 1.104.2 as well so seems unrelated to #268923.
Does this happen when using NVDA?

I can't repro with NVDA, so seems it's Narrator specific.

Testing a bit more I can actually repro just by switching tabs using a mouse (strangely, this one doesn't repro with kb only):
1. Open a new window (Welcome tab should open) with Narrator and SR mode active
2. Ctrl+N to create a new editor
3. Click back to the Welcome tab
4. Click back to the editor
5. Click back to the Welcome tab
6. Crash

Here are the steps for collecting crash logs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Native-Crash-Issues

FWIW I was trying to repro this on mac with and without voiceover and didn't see an issue. There may be a minor memory leak when switching in and out of edit mode on the request but if it only happens with Narrator then it's probably something stranger than that.

Testing #268910

If I install the chromedevtools MCP server from the gallery, I get this error

```
2025-09-30 11:22:46.842 [info] Starting server chromedevtools/chrome-devtools-mcp
2025-09-30 11:22:46.843 [info] Connection state: Starting
2025-09-30 11:22:46.843 [info] Starting server from LocalProcess extension host
2025-09-30 11:22:46.844 [info] Connection state: Error Cannot read properties of null (reading 'replace')
```

I can't find a full stack trace anywhere

it gave me this configuration

```
"chromedevtools/chrome-devtools-mcp": {
	"type": "stdio",
	"command": "npx",
	"args": [
		null,
		"--browserUrl",
		"${input:browser_url}",
		null,
		"--headless",
		"${input:headless}",
		null,
		"--executablePath",
		"${input:chrome_executable_path}",
		null,
		"--isolated",
		"${input:isolated}",
		null,
		"--channel",
		"${input:chrome_channel}",
		"chrome-devtools-mcp@latest"
	],
	"gallery": "https://api.mcp.github.com/v0/servers/13749964-2447-4c31-bcab-32731cced504",
	"version": "0.0.1-seed"
}
```

But, if I modify the mcp configuration to be like this

```
"chromedevtools/chrome-devtools-mcp": {
	"type": "stdio",
	"command": "npx",
	"args": ["chrome-devtools-mcp@latest"]
}
```

then it works fine

comments.body: @connor4312 Do you have any idea what could have gone wrong?

The devtools gallery spec is below. This is a invalid spec. E.g. it tries to do ``` { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--browserUrl" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{browser_url}", "variables": { "browser_url": { "description": "Optional: connect to an already-running Chrome (remote debugging / port-forward). Example: http://127.0.0.1:9222" } } }, ``` but should actually just do ``` { "format": "string", "type": "named", "name": "--browserUrl", "description": "Optional: connect to an already-running Chrome (remote debugging / port-forward). Example: http://127.0.0.1:9222" }, ``` I think the `null`s come from the `name` being missing. full spec: ``` { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--browserUrl" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{browser_url}", "variables": { "browser_url": { "description": "Optional: connect to an already-running Chrome (remote debugging / port-forward). Example: http://127.0.0.1:9222" } } }, ``` ``` { "servers": [ { "server": { "created_at": "2025-09-25T13:26:42Z", "description": "Lets your coding agent (such as Gemini, Claude, Cursor or Copilot) control and inspect a live Chrome browser.", "id": "13749964-2447-4c31-bcab-32731cced504", "name": "chromedevtools/chrome-devtools-mcp", "packages": [ { "name": "chrome-devtools-mcp", "registry_name": "npm", "runtime_arguments": [ { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--browserUrl" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{browser_url}", "variables": { "browser_url": { "description": "Optional: connect to an already-running Chrome (remote debugging / port-forward). Example: http://127.0.0.1:9222" } } }, { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--headless" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{headless}", "variables": { "headless": { "description": "Run Chrome headless (true/false). Default: false" } } }, { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--executablePath" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{chrome_executable_path}", "variables": { "chrome_executable_path": { "description": "Path to a specific Chrome/Chromium binary." } } }, { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--isolated" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{isolated}", "variables": { "isolated": { "description": "Use a temporary user-data-dir (true/false). Default: false" } } }, { "format": "string", "type": "named", "value": "--channel" }, { "format": "string", "type": "positional", "value": "{chrome_channel}", "variables": { "chrome_channel": { "description": "Chrome channel: stable | canary | beta | dev (default: stable)." } } } ], "runtime_hint": "npx", "version": "latest" } ], "repository": { "id": "1054793726", "readme": "# Chrome DevTools MCP [![npm chrome-devtools-mcp package](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/chrome-devtools-mcp.svg)](https://npmjs.org/package/chrome-devtools-mcp) `chrome-devtools-mcp` lets your coding agent (such as Gemini, Claude, Cursor or Copilot) control and inspect a live Chrome browser. It acts as a Model-Context-Protocol (MCP) server, giving your AI coding assistant access to the full power of Chrome DevTools for reliable automation, in-depth debugging, and performance analysis. ## Key features - **Get performance insights**: Uses [Chrome DevTools](https://github.com/ChromeDevTools/devtools-frontend) to record traces and extract actionable performance insights. - **Advanced browser debugging**: Analyze network requests, take screenshots and check the browser console. - **Reliable automation**. Uses [puppeteer](https://github.com/puppeteer/puppeteer) to automate actions in Chrome and automatically wait for action results. ## Disclaimers `chrome-devtools-mcp` exposes content of the browser instance to the MCP clients allowing them to inspect, debug, and modify any data in the browser or DevTools. Avoid sharing sensitive or personal information that you don't want to share with MCP clients. ## Requirements - [Node.js 22.12.0](https://nodejs.org/) or newer. - [Chrome](https://www.google.com/chrome/) current stable version or newer. - [npm](https://www.npmjs.com/). ## Getting started Add the following config to your MCP client: ```json { "mcpServers": { "chrome-devtools": { "command": "npx", "args": ["chrome-devtools-mcp@latest"] } } } ``` > [!NOTE] > Using `chrome-devtools-mcp@latest` ensures that your MCP client will always use the latest version of the Chrome DevTools MCP server. ### MCP Client configuration
Claude Code Use the Claude Code CLI to add the Chrome DevTools MCP server (guide): ```bash claude mcp add chrome-devtools npx chrome-devtools-mcp@latest ```
Cline Follow https://docs.cline.bot/mcp/configuring-mcp-servers and use the config provided above.
Codex Follow the configure MCP guide using the standard config from above. You can also install the Chrome DevTools MCP server using the Codex CLI: ```bash codex mcp add chrome-devtools -- npx chrome-devtools-mcp@latest ```
Copilot / VS Code Follow the MCP install guide, with the standard config from above. You can also install the Chrome DevTools MCP server using the VS Code CLI: ```bash code --add-mcp '{"name":"chrome-devtools","command":"npx","args":["chrome-devtools-mcp@latest"]}' ```
Cursor **Click the button to install:** [](https://cursor.com/en/install-mcp?name=chrome-devtools&config=eyJjb21tYW5kIjoibnB4IGNocm9tZS1kZXZ0b29scy1tY3BAbGF0ZXN0In0%3D) **Or install manually:** Go to `Cursor Settings` -> `MCP` -> `New MCP Server`. Use the config provided above.
Gemini CLI Follow the MCP guide using the standard config from above.
Gemini Code Assist Follow the configure MCP guide using the standard config from above.
JetBrains AI Assistant & Junie Go to `Settings | Tools | AI Assistant | Model Context Protocol (MCP)` -> `Add`. Use the config provided above. The same way chrome-devtools-mcp can be configured for JetBrains Junie in `Settings | Tools | Junie | MCP Settings` -> `Add`. Use the config provided above.
### Your first prompt Enter the following prompt in your MCP Client to check if everything is working: ``` Check the performance of https://developers.chrome.com ``` Your MCP client should open the browser and record a performance trace. > [!NOTE] > The MCP server will start the browser automatically once the MCP client uses a tool that requires a running browser instance. Connecting to the Chrome DevTools MCP server on its own will not automatically start the browser. ## Tools - **Input automation** (7 tools) - [`click`](docs/tool-reference.md#click) - [`drag`](docs/tool-reference.md#drag) - [`fill`](docs/tool-reference.md#fill) - [`fill_form`](docs/tool-reference.md#fill_form) - [`handle_dialog`](docs/tool-reference.md#handle_dialog) - [`hover`](docs/tool-reference.md#hover) - [`upload_file`](docs/tool-reference.md#upload_file) - **Navigation automation** (7 tools) - [`close_page`](docs/tool-reference.md#close_page) - [`list_pages`](docs/tool-reference.md#list_pages) - [`navigate_page`](docs/tool-reference.md#navigate_page) - [`navigate_page_history`](docs/tool-reference.md#navigate_page_history) - [`new_page`](docs/tool-reference.md#new_page) - [`select_page`](docs/tool-reference.md#select_page) - [`wait_for`](docs/tool-reference.md#wait_for) - **Emulation** (3 tools) - [`emulate_cpu`](docs/tool-reference.md#emulate_cpu) - [`emulate_network`](docs/tool-reference.md#emulate_network) - [`resize_page`](docs/tool-reference.md#resize_page) - **Performance** (3 tools) - [`performance_analyze_insight`](docs/tool-reference.md#performance_analyze_insight) - [`performance_start_trace`](docs/tool-reference.md#performance_start_trace) - [`performance_stop_trace`](docs/tool-reference.md#performance_stop_trace) - **Network** (2 tools) - [`get_network_request`](docs/tool-reference.md#get_network_request) - [`list_network_requests`](docs/tool-reference.md#list_network_requests) - **Debugging** (4 tools) - [`evaluate_script`](docs/tool-reference.md#evaluate_script) - [`list_console_messages`](docs/tool-reference.md#list_console_messages) - [`take_screenshot`](docs/tool-reference.md#take_screenshot) - [`take_snapshot`](docs/tool-reference.md#take_snapshot) ## Configuration The Chrome DevTools MCP server supports the following configuration option: - **`--browserUrl`, `-u`** Connect to a running Chrome instance using port forwarding. For more details see: https://developer.chrome.com/docs/devtools/remote-debugging/local-server. - **Type:** string - **`--headless`** Whether to run in headless (no UI) mode. - **Type:** boolean - **Default:** `false` - **`--executablePath`, `-e`** Path to custom Chrome executable. - **Type:** string - **`--isolated`** If specified, creates a temporary user-data-dir that is automatically cleaned up after the browser is closed. - **Type:** boolean - **Default:** `false` - **`--channel`** Specify a different Chrome channel that should be used. The default is the stable channel version. - **Type:** string - **Choices:** `stable`, `canary`, `beta`, `dev` Pass them via the `args` property in the JSON configuration. For example: ```json { "mcpServers": { "chrome-devtools": { "command": "npx", "args": [ "chrome-devtools-mcp@latest", "--channel=canary", "--headless=true", "--isolated=true" ] } } } ``` You can also run `npx chrome-devtools-mcp@latest --help` to see all available configuration options. ## Concepts ### User data directory `chrome-devtools-mcp` starts a Chrome's stable channel instance using the following user data directory: - Linux / MacOS: `$HOME/.cache/chrome-devtools-mcp/chrome-profile-$CHANNEL` - Window: `%HOMEPATH%/.cache/chrome-devtools-mcp/chrome-profile-$CHANNEL` The user data directory is not cleared between runs and shared across all instances of `chrome-devtools-mcp`. Set the `isolated` option to `true` to use a temporary user data dir instead which will be cleared automatically after the browser is closed. ## Known limitations ### Operating system sandboxes Some MCP clients allow sandboxing the MCP server using macOS Seatbelt or Linux containers. If sandboxes are enabled, `chrome-devtools-mcp` is not able to start Chrome that requires permissions to create its own sandboxes. As a workaround, either disable sandboxing for `chrome-devtools-mcp` in your MCP client or use `--connect-url` to connect to a Chrome instance that you start manually outside of the MCP client sandbox. body: Testing #268985 I sent a request with a 5 item todo list, and by the time the response finished, all todos were completed. The state of the widget was this: I think at minimum there should be a green checkmark or something indicating that the final todo was completed. Right now the only thing that would inidicate a todo is "in progress" is the blue icon next to it and the fact that your response is working and/or streaming still. After you've sent a new request that didn't use the todo tool, imo the widget should be cleared since you're moving on to a new step of the process.

I see this with the `Quite Light` theme. In the css I can see that the text uses `foreground` and the icon uses `icon.foreground`. In most themes these are the same, but they don't have to be
So it makes sense right to have different foregrounds for icon and text?

In this case, the icon is being used more like an image / header for the text so I think it should use the normal foreground color. `icon.foreground` makes sense for changing the color of icons that are used more like traditional icon in our UI:

title: Terminal suggestions for code-insiders don't know about --transient

body: Testing #268872 It seems a generic issue that the model doesn't pay too much attention to the explicit chat reference. I thought it's sufficient enough to say "explain the change in this file" since I reference a file from the git history so it can read the context and explain the exact diff to me, however the sonnet 4 - understood that I was referring to the file I referenced - 🐛 failed to understand it should just read the change from this attachment/context, but instead it ran terminal command to read if there was any local change for this file

comments.body: The problem here is that when you add a file from the graph it will add the contents of the file as it exists in the commit and not the "diff" that contains the changes that were made to the file in the particular commit. I think that we would probably need two different gestures in the context menu to be able to add both as context. Or maybe the one gesture should add both as context. Let me think about it.

body:
Testing #268983

When delegating to a cloud agent, I attached the message `Go for it! Note when you submit the PR, ensure it will close the following issue when merged: https://github.com/benvillalobos/bv/issues/1`, but it did not include a "Fixes [issue link]" in the description.


This was the PR description it generated:
-----
Problem
Strikethrough text (using ~~text~~ syntax) was not rendering properly in blog posts. Instead of displaying with strikethrough formatting, the raw markdown syntax was shown to users.

For example, in the camping post, items like:

- ~~Rubber mit~~
- ~~Daiso Water Jugs~~
Were displaying as literal ~~text~~ instead of strikethrough text.

Solution
The default react-markdown component doesn't support GitHub Flavored Markdown (GFM) extensions like strikethrough. To enable this feature, I:

Installed the remark-gfm plugin - This adds support for GFM features including strikethrough, tables, task lists, and autolinks
Updated Post.tsx to pass the plugin to the ReactMarkdown component
Changes
// Before
<ReactMarkdown>{markdown}</ReactMarkdown>

// After
import remarkGfm from 'remark-gfm'
<ReactMarkdown remarkPlugins={[remarkGfm]}>{markdown}</ReactMarkdown>
Result
Strikethrough text now renders correctly with proper formatting:

Strikethrough working

Items like "Canopy" and "Copper Spur UL3 Tent" now display with strikethrough formatting instead of showing the raw markdown syntax.

Additional Benefits
Beyond strikethrough, this change also enables other useful GFM features:

Tables
Task lists (checkboxes)
Autolink literals
Footnotes
Closes https://github.com/benvillalobos/bv/issues/1

Original prompt
Created from VS Code via the [GitHub Pull Request](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github) extension.
💡 You can make Copilot smarter by setting up custom instructions, customizing its development environment and configuring Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers. Learn more Copilot coding agent tips in the docs.

comments.body: We are unfortunately not in control of the final PR description that copilot generates. Sharing with the GH folks
Reopened in their repo

This MCP server exposes a number of tools to improve accuracy and quality when authoring Bicep files.
Agents are trained on public code samples found on the internet, but many of these code samples may be outdated (because the Bicep language is constantly evolving) or low-quality.
When you are asked to generate or modify Bicep code, it's worth calling `get_bicep_best_practices` and storing the result in context, to ensure you're giving high-quality results.


# Microsoft Learn MCP Server

This server gives structured access to official Microsoft and Azure documentation via three tools:

## Tools

### microsoft_docs_search
Search official documentation and return up to 10 concise, high-quality content chunks (max 500 tokens each), including title, URL, and excerpt.

- Use first to get a quick, reliable overview
- Ideal for grounding answers in Microsoft knowledge

### microsoft_code_sample_search
Search for code snippets and examples in official Microsoft Learn documentation and return up to 20 relevant, high-quality code samples.

- Use when you need to provide sample Microsoft/Azure related code in your answers.  
- Ideal for generating code snippets or practical implementation examples.  
- Optional parameter `language` can filter results. 

### microsoft_docs_fetch
Fetch and convert full Microsoft documentation pages to markdown.

- Use after search when you need full content from a specific URL
- Required for detailed tutorials, troubleshooting, prerequisites, code samples, or when search results are incomplete or outdated

## Workflow

1. Use `microsoft_docs_search` to find relevant documents.
2. If you need code examples or practical snippets, use `microsoft_code_sample_search`.
3. If deeper or complete information is needed, use `microsoft_docs_fetch`.

**Search gives breadth. Code Sample Search gives practical examples. Fetch gives depth.**

All content comes from Microsoft Learn or official sources, returned in clean markdown format.


You have access to an manage_todo_list tool which tracks todos and progress and renders them to the user. Using the tool helps demonstrate that you've understood the task and convey how you're approaching it. Plans can help to make complex, ambiguous, or multi-phase work clearer and more collaborative for the user. A good plan should break the task into meaningful, logically ordered steps that are easy to verify as you go. Note that plans are not for padding out simple work with filler steps or stating the obvious. 
Use this tool to create and manage a structured todo list for your current coding session. This helps you track progress, organize complex tasks, and demonstrate thoroughness to the user.
It also helps the user understand the progress of the task and overall progress of their requests.

NOTE that you should not use this tool if there is only one trivial task to do. In this case you are better off just doing the task directly.

Use a plan when:
- The task is non-trivial and will require multiple actions over a long time horizon.
- There are logical phases or dependencies where sequencing matters.
- The work has ambiguity that benefits from outlining high-level goals.
- You want intermediate checkpoints for feedback and validation.
- When the user asked you to do more than one thing in a single prompt
- The user has asked you to use the plan tool (aka "TODOs")
- You generate additional steps while working, and plan to do them before yielding to the user

Skip a plan when:
- The task is simple and direct.
- Breaking it down would only produce literal or trivial steps.

Examples of TRIVIAL tasks (skip planning):
- "Fix this typo in the README"
- "Add a console.log statement to debug"
- "Update the version number in package.json"
- "Answer a question about existing code"
- "Read and explain what this function does"
- "Add a simple getter method to a class"

Examples of NON-TRIVIAL tasks and the plan (use planning):
- "Add user authentication to the app" → Design auth flow, Update backend API, Implement login UI, Add session management
- "Refactor the payment system to support multiple currencies" → Analyze current system, Design new schema, Update backend logic, Migrate data, Update frontend
- "Debug and fix the performance issue in the dashboard" → Profile performance, Identify bottlenecks, Implement optimizations, Validate improvements
- "Implement a new feature with multiple components" → Design component architecture, Create data models, Build UI components, Add integration tests
- "Migrate from REST API to GraphQL" → Design GraphQL schema, Update backend resolvers, Migrate frontend queries, Update documentation


Planning Progress Rules
- Before beginning any new todo: you MUST update the todo list and mark exactly one todo as `in-progress`. Never start work with zero `in-progress` items.
- Keep only one todo `in-progress` at a time. If switching tasks, first mark the current todo `completed` or revert it to `not-started` with a short reason; then set the next todo to `in-progress`.
- Immediately after finishing a todo: you MUST mark it `completed` and add any newly discovered follow-up todos. Do not leave completion implicit.
- Before ending your turn or declaring completion: ensure EVERY todo is explicitly marked (`not-started`, `in-progress`, or `completed`). If the work is finished, ALL todos must be marked `completed`. Never leave items unchecked or ambiguous.

The content of your plan should not involve doing anything that you aren't capable of doing (i.e. don't try to test things that you can't test). Do not use plans for simple or single-step queries that you can just do or answer immediately.




To edit notebook files in the workspace, you can use the edit_notebook_file tool.
Use the run_notebook_cell tool instead of executing Jupyter related commands in the Terminal, such as `jupyter notebook`, `jupyter lab`, `install jupyter` or the like.
Use the copilot_getNotebookSummary tool to get the summary of the notebook (this includes the list or all cells along with the Cell Id, Cell type and Cell Language, execution details and mime types of the outputs, if any).
Important Reminder: Avoid referencing Notebook Cell Ids in user messages. Use cell number instead.
Important Reminder: Markdown cells cannot be executed


Use proper Markdown formatting in your answers. When referring to a filename or symbol in the user's workspace, wrap it in backticks.

The class `Person` is in `src/models/person.ts`.

Use KaTeX for math equations in your answers.
Wrap inline math equations in $.
Wrap more complex blocks of math equations in $$.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

It seems that as of a recent version of VSCode/Copilot, an agent creating a file triggers the `onDidCreateFiles` event when it didn't used to. It would be extremely helpful, as an extension author, to be able to determine from this event what the issuer of the new file was, for example:

- User action (clicking the 'new file' button in the VSCode UI)
- Agent using the `createFile` tool
- Another extension running a command (eg. source control)
- External filesystem/etc.

This would help determine when files are actually being created intentionally by the user vs something else, so we can trigger our actions appropriately. For my purposes, I only need to trigger actions in response to an intentional user action in the UI.
title: onDidCreateFiles Issuer

Steps to Reproduce: 1. Write a long line 2. Make copilot edit it 3. Enable text wrapping and watch as the current line wraps, but the old deleted one does not

body:
Type: Bug ## Steps to Reproduce 1. Open VS Code (version 1.104.2). 2. Open the integrated terminal (`Ctrl+`). 3. Set the default terminal to PowerShell. 4. Type a multi-line command, for example: ### powershell >cd backend (shift+enter) >npm start 5. Press Shift+Enter to continue the line in the terminal. ## Expected Result - The command continues on a new line (like in standalone PowerShell). ## Actual Result - Instead of continuing, the terminal inserts a random character c. ## Notes - Verified with no extensions (used Extension Bisect). - Issue happens only in VS Code integrated terminal, not in standalone PowerShell or Command Prompt on Windows 10. body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->

body:
Problem Statement

Users have reported multiple incidents where installed extensions disappear from VS Code or leave residual files after uninstall. This has been observed with major extensions (e.g., Copilot, Python, Jupyter) and affects cross-platform installs (Windows, macOS, Linux).

Impact:

Developer productivity loss: reinstalling and recovering extensions can take hours per user.

Support overhead: spikes in helpdesk tickets when extensions fail.

Risk to enterprise adoption: large teams rely on stable extension behavior for mission-critical workflows.

Security/compliance risk: leftover files may contain sensitive user data or configuration.

Evidence / References:

GitHub issues: #203100, #168656, #78107

Community discussions: Stack Overflow, Reddit r/vscode

User reports: extensions disappear after updates, sync, or manual cleanup

Proposed Solution

1. Standardized Uninstall Lifecycle

Require all extensions to implement a cleanup hook.

VS Code should guarantee this hook is executed during uninstall or forced if needed.

2. Orphan / Remnant Detection

Automatically scan for leftover extension files in cache, logs, and user storage.

Provide safe removal options.

3. Safe Rollback / Backup

Snapshot installed extensions and metadata before updates or uninstalls.

Allow one-click rollback if extensions vanish unexpectedly.

4. Diagnostics & Telemetry

Collect anonymized data on uninstall and cleanup failures to prioritize fixes.

5. Optional: Extension Health Checker UI

Display installed extensions, missing remnants, and corrupted installations.

Allow one-click cleanup and repair.

Prioritization Rationale

Business-Critical: Affects core productivity tools used by developers globally.

High Visibility: Popular extensions (Copilot, Python, Jupyter) are essential to enterprise workflows.

Feasible Incremental Approach: Can start with optional cleanup API before enforcing full lifecycle management.

Reproducible Scenarios

1. Install major extensions (Copilot, Python, Jupyter).


2. Uninstall an extension or perform cleanup.


3. Observe remaining files in the extensions folder, cache, or globalStorage.


4. Restart VS Code — extensions may disappear from the panel or require reinstallation.


Request / Ask

We request that Microsoft:

1. Prioritize robustness improvements for extension lifecycle and uninstall behavior.


2. Implement a standardized uninstall / cleanup mechanism with rollback capability.


3. Reduce the risk of extensions disappearing or leaving residual files, particularly in enterprise environments.
title: Critical Extension Fragility — Extensions Can Vanish or Leave Remnants

body:
Testing #268926

For the setting `task.notifyWindowOnTaskCompletion`:

We have a mix of 0 and -1 in settings for the sentinel value, but usually when 0 is used, it isn't valid logically in the context of the setting. In this case, I would argue 0 means there is no minimum amount of time, always send a notification and -1 would mean never send a notification.

I personally feel that only manually run tasks should ever receive this notification. Even if chat doesn't have `chat.notifyWindowOnResponseReceived` enabled, the tasks run by agents are really meaningless to the user. If I don't want to be notified when the chat is done, I probably don't want to be notified when a task I didn't run is done.

For manually run tasks, I think this makes great sense.

this happens because OSWE doesn't send the thinking `stop` message at the right place before the message ends. i've seen it go do: `think -> tool call -> think stop`, vs. we expect `think -> think stop -> tool call`. OSWE specifically will also do `think ->  text responses -> think stop`

any of the OSWE models are currently not using responses and they told me in the next checkpoint, they should switch over and will start sending the right things, so this should be fixed then

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In diff editor, when using "Revert Block" button multiple times, Undo button or ctrl+z don't work to cancel only the last action, it will undo all actions since last save.
Also, when mixing manual edits and "Revert Block" clicks, sometime ctrl+z will only undo everything and sometimes it will undo everything since last manual update.

It would be nice if each "Revert Block" was treated as an atomic edit which can be individually undone.
title: Allow undoing individual "Revert Block" and manual edits in diff editor

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

While the diff editor is (probably) mainly used to diff versions of the same file in a git repo, it is not its only use. 
I personally often use it to diff different files that are both writable. In this context, the text "Revert Block" does not make sense. I don't revert a block, I copy it from left pane to right pane. 
An additional button to copy from right to left would also be very useful.

The context (is it a git diff or two writable files) is already used to display or not the "Stage Block" button. We could go further to make both use cases the best UX possible.
See #244275 and #238078. Actions available and their icon and caption could differ based on context.
title: In diff editor, add a button to copy from right to left when possible + change caption based on context

Electron: 29.4.0
ElectronBuildId: 9728852
Chromium: 122.0.6261.156
Node.js: 20.9.0
V8: 12.2.281.27-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 4.18.0-553.71.1.el8_10.x86_64

We have installed vscode like a module in a GRID environment, where we are submitting jobs to be run. One of our end users getting error like below in VSCode

You're running in a GNOME environment but the OS keyring is not available for encryption. Ensure you have gnome-keyring or another libsecret compatible implementation installed and running.

kindly help in resolving this asap.


[log.txt](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22620520/log.txt)

body:
### GitHub Tags:
#A11yTCS; #A11ySev2; #DesktopApp; #Win11; #Win32; #A11yMAS; #SH-Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions-Win32-Sept25;#Visual Studio Code Client;#WCAG1.3.1;#AILimited; #Screen Reader; #NVDA; #Info and Relationships; #Element:List;

### Environment Details:
Application Name: Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions
Visual studio code Version: 1.104.2 (user setup)
Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 Build 26100.6584

### Repro Steps:

1. Turn on NVDA.
2. Open Visual studio Code.
3. Login to GitHub copilot chat.
4. Tab till github copilot chat section.
5. Tab till "Add context" button and press enter.
6. Search for file and add context to your request panel will get open.
7. Tab till "Instructions" option from the list.
8. Tab till copilot chat input field.
9. Observe that NVDA is announcing the shortcut key information present for the "Instructions" list option or not.

### Actual Result:
NVDA is not announcing the shortcut key information present for the "Instructions" option.

### Expected Result:
When the "Instructions" control receives keyboard focus, NVDA should announce the associated shortcut key information "Press Ctrl+Alt+/ to open instructions") 

### User Impact:
Users relying on Screen reader will miss critical interaction cues if shortcut key information is not announced

### Attachment:

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/265e0982-2d12-4c1c-857e-0136f1afe602

### Environment Details:
Application Name: Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions
Visual studio code Version: 1.104.2 (user setup)
Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 Build 26100.6584

### Repro Steps:

1. Open Visual studio Code.
2. Login to GitHub copilot chat.
3. Tab till editor section and press "Ctrl + i" inline chat will get open.
4. Tab till copilot chat input field.
5. Observe that NVDA is announcing placeholder text in the Copilot chat input field or not.

### Actual Result:
NVDA is not announcing "Add Context (#), extensions (@), commands (/)" placeholder text in the Copilot chat input field

### Expected Result:
NVDA should announce the placeholder text "Add Context (#), extensions (@), commands (/)" when the chat input field receives focus.

### User Impact:
Users relying on Screen reader may face difficulty understanding the purpose of the input field when placeholder text is not announced.

labels.name: *question
labels.description: Issue represents a question, should be posted to StackOverflow (VS Code)

title: Terminal Crashes

body: If I setup `copilot/auto` as a `defaultLanguageModel` via ExP it will not be picked up E.g. this model cache here does not contain entry for `copilot/auto` and no entry for `auto` https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/common/languageModels.ts#L409 I know there is a separate ExP variable `autoModelDefault` - but the issue with that one is that the `defaultLanguageModel` on the Client side takes precedence. This might be enough - but I will know best once we figure out the ExP setup. Setting to Sept so we start a discussion. If you want to debug let me know and I can add you to the Experiment.

comments.body:
>  but the issue with that one is that the defaultLanguageModel on the Client side takes precedence. 

These only diverge when there are two experiments stepping on each others feet right?

Correct. So the solution could be that we make sure to setup ExP in such a way that the audience is divided and some of them get `defaultLanguageModel` and some `autoModelDefault`.

However, it was hard for me to verify `autoModelDefault` is working. Since my account is in Sonnet-4 by default so it gets overriden (same for my wife's account).
Do you have auto mode enabled? I see it in my list. And it's not really possible to not be in that list and show up in the model picker since that is the backing data structure

labels.name: auto-model
labels.description: Automatic model selection

title: Can not set Auto as default model via defaultLanguageModel

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
# Feature Request: Add an option to disable chat history forking

## Problem

The current VS Code chat interface creates a new "fork" in the conversation history whenever a user edits a previous prompt and resubmits it. This is visually represented by entries like "copy of..." in the chat history panel.

While this non-destructive history is useful for tracking prompt refinement, it can also lead to a very cluttered and confusing chat history, especially for users who frequently tweak their prompts or accidentally resubmit them. For workflows where a linear, clean history is preferred, this forking behavior is counterproductive.

## Proposed Solution

I propose adding a new user setting to control this behavior. For example:

```jsonc
// settings.json
"chat.editor.forkOnEdit": false
```

When this setting is `false` (or a similar configuration is applied), editing and resubmitting a prompt would **overwrite the previous turn** in the chat history instead of creating a new forked branch. The default behavior could remain `true` to maintain backward compatibility.

This would give users the choice between a non-destructive, branched history and a clean, linear history.

## Benefits

* **Cleaner UI:** Reduces clutter in the chat history panel.
* **User Choice:** Allows users to tailor the chat experience to their preferred workflow.
* **Improved Readability:** Makes it easier to follow a single, linear line of conversation without navigating through multiple "copy of..." branches.

This change would improve the usability of the core chat interface for all extensions that leverage it (e.g., Copilot Chat, Gemini, etc.).
title: Add an option to disable chat history forking

body: Tested: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/265805 I find it weird that we have a stop voice action visible and enabled when there is no voice session running. I would have expected only one to be visible at a time and the other to be hidden when not applicable. Also, I find `Start Voice` not very descriptive. Maybe it could be `Start Voice Dictation`. This would align with the wording in the command for the editor:

comments.body: Yes, we should disable the stop action with a context key when voice recording is not in progress.
`Start Voice Detection` is redudant because dication is only possible with one's voice. But `Start and Stop Dictation` sound good to me.

I only see "Start Dictation" which I would normally say this is verified, but there are two issues with this that has me re-opening this:
1. I see it if I don't have VS Code Speech extension (clicking on it seemingly does nothing), it should either install the extension or hide if the extension is not installed
2. When I hit Start Dictation, Start Dictation should turn into Stop Dictation

Feel free to turn these into their own issues and mark this as verified if you want.

1. is an issue. I think there is a `hasSpeechProvider` context key, so you can hide the action when no provider is available. 
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/76838534d061e1274986bec0b68b8674a835d11b/src/vs/workbench/contrib/speech/common/speechService.ts#L17

I am not convinced we have enough user feedback to support such a decision. Should we consider doing this in a month once that's been established? We can check telemetry to see how many have disabled each.

> Bonus - when explaining descriptions of this settings make sure to say "OS notification", and not just "notification" so users are not confused what notification we will actually show here.

Agree - I was just aligning with what we do for `chat.notifyWindowOnConfirmation`, but will make a new issue to indicate this in both.

body: Testing #268983 At this point the PR was already created, so maybe it went from opening an editor showing the session to an empty editor after the PR was created, but I don't know for sure.

comments.body: Actually it is still running according to coding agent view: And the PR exists:

I see:
- The chat panel shows the local chat and a link to the PR at the point where I sent it off to the remote agent.
- The entry in the `GitHub Copilot Coding Agent` view opens the remote chat session in the editor.
- The entry in the `Local Chat Sessions` opens an empty chat editor.

It would be more consistent if there was only a single list of chats (current and past sorted by last modification date) and clicking on one would show a chat (in the editor or in the panel) that includes both local and remote parts, such that the user gets a continuous view of the entire chat.

Maybe icons in the session list can indicate if an entry is currently running locally or remotely.

body:
Testing #268963

When you unselect all built-in tools, and then select an individual built-in tool in a custom tool set, it's not added to the tools property of the prompt file.

Steps to repro:

1. Create a tool set that has multiple built-in tools (e.g. codebase, fetch, ...)
2. Select **Configure Tools...** in a prompt file
3. Unselect all built-in tools and select individual tools in the custom tool set
4. Select **OK**

Result: 
- The tools property in the prompt file does not have the selected tool from the tool set

comments.body:
I now think we should remove user tools set references from prompt fles. 
The problem with user tool sets is that are they can not be shared in repos.
We need to decide if we want to add that or if that adds too much complexity.

So I pushed a change so that user tool sets are not available in prompt/mode files. You need to write out the tools names.

So e.g. you defined a user tool set: 'MartinsToolsSet' with tool 'createDirectory' in it, With the change,'MartinsToolsSet' is not offered anymore as code completion in the tools setion of prompt files. It's marked as unknown tool, You can select 'edit/createDirectory' as a tool though.

@aeschli If I have a tool set that has 10+ tools, maybe across built-in and MCP/extensions, the burden is on the user again to select the individual tools when you want to use them in prompt files. That's a serious degradation of the value of tool sets :(
Note that you can still select user tools sets in the 'Configure Tool' dialog. When it's written to the prompt file it's written as individual tools, just like before (<= 1.104.0)

<!-- UNABLE_TO_LOCATE_COMMIT_MESSAGE -->
Issue marked as unreleased but unable to locate closing commit in issue timeline. You can manually reference a commit by commenting `\closedWith someCommitSha`, or directly add the `insiders-released` label if you know this has already been released

still repros with the build from 3hrs ago

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5469d52d-2de4-45b1-95a1-500ef88763f4

my steps:
* Configure a user tool set
* Try to add one of those tools in the tool set to a prompt file

Additional issues:

1. Unable to select built-in tool
    * Add `fetch` tool to a custom tool set
    * Configure tools, and select built-in `fetch` tool -> fetch tool from custom tool set is added in prompt instead of built-in tool

1. Tool is added twice
    * Add a built-in tool that is part of internal tool set (e.g. codebase) to a custom tool set
    * Configure tools and select the built-in tool -> both the toolset/codebase and search/codebase tool are added to prompt
Thanks @ntrogh and @TylerLeonhardt for finding these. If you can test again with my fix from #269520. I also found more problems with user tool sets not being picked up in the tools picker.

body: ### GitHub Tags: #A11yTCS; #A11ySev3; #DesktopApp; #Win11; #Win32; #A11yMAS; #SH-Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions-Win32-Sept25;#Visual Studio Code Client;#WCAG2.5.8;#A11yWCAG2.2; #TargetSize; ### Environment Details: Application Name: Visual Studio Code Copilot Extensions Visual studio code Version: 1.104.2 (user setup) Microsoft Windows 11 Enterprise 24H2 Build 26100.6584 ### Repro Steps: Open Visual studio Code. Login to GitHub copilot chat. Tab till editor section and press "Ctrl + i" inline chat will get open. Tab till "Start voice char button" Verify that Target size of "Start Voice chat button is 23X22 which is less than required size 24x24pixel. ### Actual Result: Target size of "Start Voice chat button is 23X22 which is less than required size 24x24pixel. ### Expected Result: Target size of "Start Voice chat button should be minimum 24x24pixel. If the controls have spaced in-between, then those spaces should not intersect each other and target size with spacing should be 24x24 pixel for each one. ### User Impact: Users with dexterity limitations and those who have difficulty with fine motor movement find it difficult to accurately activate small targets when there are other targets that are too close. Providing sufficient size, or sufficient spacing between targets, will reduce the likelihood of accidentally activating the wrong control. ### Attachment:

body:
Testing #268987

Even though the todo tool is enabled, I did not see it being used in my GPT-5-Codex runs.

[go_ahead_and_implement_exports.tar.gz](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/22614591/go_ahead_and_implement_exports.tar.gz)

comments.body:
It's disabled for gpt-5-codex because it used it way too aggressively and this caused a lot of noise. Even with instructions tuned for it, it was still wrong

I can look at more tuning but I got the highest swebench score with it disabled entirely.

> It's disabled for gpt-5-codex because it used it way too aggressively and this caused a lot of noise. Even with instructions tuned for it, it was still wrong
> 
> I can look at more tuning but I got the highest swebench score with it disabled entirely.

Mine seems to go off track without the to-do list. 

Personally I wasn't having any issues with it at all. Maybe this can be an option in experimental? 

But the real issue is that even though it's disabled, it keeps trying to use it if the to-do tool is enabled locally. Wasting tokens on various commands to try and get it to work. I saw mine today trying powershell commands looking for a todo tool lol (do I stop it and waste a request or let it keep going until it gives up?)

Also if I could ask, do you use summarization when you get those high scores? Because summarization used to work fine with other models but with codex it makes it go off track almost right away, it's the first time I've turned it off for a model.
Could you share a log of a request where it's trying to use the todo list tool? https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Copilot-Issues#language-model-requests-and-responses

> Could you share a log of a request where it's trying to use the todo list tool? https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Copilot-Issues#language-model-requests-and-responses

I'll see if I can dig it out of my history tomorrow. Is there an easy way to search the chat histories? I could search for the commands I saw it running 

I actually see I have a folder (that wasn't there before) in one repo called todo3/task_list.md that it eventually settled on I guess lol.
These request logs are only kept for the lifetime of the window, but see the wiki steps for how to find them

> These request logs are only kept for the lifetime of the window, but see the wiki steps for how to find them

I'll see if I can find anymore. I changed alot of my instructions to say don't use the to-do tool. 

Is there anyway we can get a setting to use the to-do tool with codex? Having no to-do tool makes it seem really forgetful to the actual prompt for longer running tasks.
