body: Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268899 - [x] anyOS @meganrogge - [x] anyOS @aeschli - [x] anyOS @dbaeumer Complexity: 4 [Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23268902%0A%0A&assignees=alexr00) --- Setup - Install Copilot Chat and sign in. - If you already have another repo that's set up to run tests using VS Code's built in testing infrastructure, please use that repo for testing! - If not, you can use microsoft/vscode: - Make sure you have the VS Code Selfhost Test Provider workspace extension installed - Open a *.test.ts file and make sure that you see the "run test" arrow in the gutter so that you know you're set up ok. Testing > **NOTE** The llm really wants to run tests via the command line instead of the test tool. If it tries to do this, don't let it and instead ask it to use the `runTests` tool. > **NOTE** if you see the coverage view disappear from the Testing view container, that means the llm decided to use the runTests tool without the coverage flag. If this happens, you might need to prompt it to run the tool with coverage. - Find a chunk of code in your repo that already has some tests, but that you want to get to 100% test coverage (or at least get greater test coverage). Select it. - In Copilot Chat, use agent mode to ask Copilot to add tests for the selection. I recommend GPT-5. - It should try to run the tests at some point. If it tries to run with the terminal, stop it and tell it to use the `runTests` tool. This is a known issue. - You can see the test coverage in the Test Coverage view. Verify that as Copilot adds tests that the code coverage goes up.

`description` in TodoList isn't user visible and potentially a lot of tokens that we are not sure always helps the model with better short-term context.

Add a new setting `chat.todoListTool.descriptionField`, default enabled.

If disable:
- Hide description the the todo list tool input parameters
- Don't add description in the tool read and todo list markdown
- In the todo list, don't show the description in tooltip (but just the title)

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
Currently, VS Code does not provide a way for extensions to specify text direction for languages that are written right-to-left (RTL), which leads to incorrect rendering since the editor assumes left-to-right (LTR).

I propose introducing a new `textDirection` field in [languageConfiguration](https://code.visualstudio.com/api/language-extensions/language-configuration-guide) that accepts `"ltr"` or `"rtl"`, with `"ltr"` as the default. There is already an implementation for RTL based on Decorations (see PR: #255455), so this would build on existing support. If the maintainers agrees, I would be happy to work on a PR for this feature.

comments.body: Any update on this?

title: Support textDirection in languageConfiguration for RTL languages

body:
Refs: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/255801

- [x] anyOS @pierceboggan
- [x] anyOS @hediet

Complexity: 5


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23268883%0A%0A&assignees=lszomoru)

---

This milestone we have added a new editor content action in order to leverage AI to resolve merge conflicts. The editor actions is currently only added to the editor and using AI is not yet available in the 3-way merge editor. That is something that we will be looking at in the upcoming milestones.

### Prerequisites
1. Install the latest VS Code Insiders release
2. Install the latest Copilot Chat pre-release extension

### Resolve merge conflicts
1. Launch VS Code and open a folder/workspace that contains a git repository
2. Generate a merge conflict by one of the following (pull from remote, merge two branches, rebase branch, apply a stash)
3. Open a file from the "Merge Changes" source control resource group
    * Confirm that in the lower right hand corner you see the "Resolve in Merge Editor" and "Chat Sparkle" actions
4. Click on the "Chat Sparkle" action
    * Confirm that an agent mode chat session is started
    * Confirm that the following context is added (current file, base, current branch, incoming branch)
5. Review the output of the chat session
6. Review the merge conflict resolution proposed by the language model
7. Please feel free to share scenarion in which the resolution was correct/not correct (use Copilot Chat Debug information) 

### Trigger setup through the action
1. Launch VS Code using `code-insiders --transient`
2. Open a folder/workspace that contains a git repository
3. Generate a merge conflict by one of the following (pull from remote, merge two branches, rebase branch, apply a stash)
4. Open a file from the "Merge Changes" source control resource group
    * Confirm that in the lower right hand corner you see the "Resolve in Merge Editor" and "Chat Sparkle" actions
5. Click on the "Chat Sparkle" action
    * Confirm that you are taken through the Copilot Setup flow
    * Confirm that the merge commit resolution context/message is sent in an agent mode chat session

comments.body: Nice work!

I am very excited we're exploring this!

The agent was able to successfully resolve my merge conflict between two branches but had trouble when attempting to resolve conflicts between two Git work trees. I logged two additional issues related to feature discoverability, and another around strengthening the prompt for resolving conflicts.

Is there any telemetry that would speak to the user success with this metric we can track?

title: Test: Chat - resolve merge conflicts

<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.105.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a chat mode that uses mcp tool, `npm init playwright@next -- --next --agents=vscode`, accept defaults
2. Start code-insiders
3. Pick Planner agent and issue a command

Command is not using the planner agent MCP and results in a guaranteed failure because of the fine print above: "The MCP server playwright-test may have new tools and requires interaction to start. Start it now?". 

Please make sure MCPs are all accepted before committing the task to the agent.

comments.body: This is because we have the trust prompt for workspace-included MCP servers However now that we have our sensitive file protection for `.vscode/*.json`, we may be able to get rid of this because it's no longer the case that someone can prompt-inject mcp.json silently. What do you think @Tyriar?

That's the fine print I was referring to. It appears after the prompt is submitted, i.e. it sets up user for imminent failure. All I'm asking is that the permission is requested before I am able to submit the prompt. Disabling the input before I grant permission also works for me, just make sure chat mode is never used unless all of its mcp requirements are met.

## Issue with wrong Auth Server being used and Redirect URI not working properly
Is it somehow possible to provide the authorizaiton server? DCR doesn't work in our scenario and the fallback client credential flow seems to use the wrong authorization server. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add new MCP Server to Workspace (URL of MCP Server behind Azure APIM)
2. Start MCP Server 
3. DCR is not supported therefore proceed with manually created client registration which has redirect uris (http://127.0.0.1:33418 and https://vscode.dev/redirect )
4. Added Client ID and Secret within VSCode prompt
5. MCP Server wants to authenticate to: "URL-OF-APIM" -> same as the MCP Server URL -> BUT it should use the microsoft entra id Auth server and I don't see any option to provide the authorization server?
6. I can copy the generated authorize? url and replace the wrong authorization url with the correct one + add additionally required scopes (Can scope be provided?, seems to be required)
7. After that I can login in the Browser with my Microsoft account, but the redirect doesn't seem to work (127.0.0.1 refused to connect / in terminal I can't see any process listening on 33418), like VSCode isn't listening on the port 33418 (I've tried it with all the different VSCode versions mentioned above)

comments.body: Is there a reason your MCP server's Protected Resource Metadata doesn't mention Entra's auth URL? VS Code supports Microsoft auth without needing DCR (because we have a client id in vscode). This flow is a lot nicer than the flow you're playing with

Seems like the issue ist with Azure APIM which is before the MCP server (not using Azure APIM specific MCP functionality). The requests do not properly go the the MCP Server its asking the the APIM directly for metadata which is not working properly because there is no resource listening on the APIM for /.well-known/oauth-protected-resource
@nasan92 based on that, it sounds like you wanna chat with the APIM folks. I don't think this has any action item for VS Code, but correct me if I'm wrong.

@wolfpackt99 can you open a new issue, also provide the logs of your server: 

Can you follow these steps so that we can get more information on what's going on?

#### Enable trace logging

* Open the Command Palette (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Trace`, click the *double* check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (enables trace logging as the default)

_Now wait for the issue to happen or trigger it..._

#### Getting the logs

* Open the Command Palette again (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `MCP: List Servers` command
* Choose your server
* `Show Output`
* Copy and paste the contents of what opens in the panel in this issue (if the contents is too large, you may need to upload it as a file)

#### Reverting trace logging (optional)

When we're done here, to revert the log level back to the default:
* Open the Command Palette
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Info`, click the double check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (to set the default back to info)

- [x] anyOS @rebornix
- [x] anyOS @sandy081

Complexity: 2


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23268872%0A%0A&assignees=lszomoru)

---

This milestone we have added the capability to attach a history item change (ex: a file from a particular commit) as chat context.

### Prerequisites
1. Install the latest VS Code Insiders release
2. Install the latest Copilot Chat pre-release extension

### Add Context from Graph View
1. Open a folder/workspace that contains a git repository
2. Open the Source Control Graph view
3. Click on a commit in the graph in order to reveal its contents
4. Right click on a file in the commit and choose Add to Chat    
    * Confirm that the chat panel is opened if not already opened
    * Confirm that the file was attached as context
4. Click on the attachment pill in the chat panel
    * Confirm that the file is opened at the correct version in read-only mode
6. Type in a message that would leverage the new context    
    * Confirm that the response is appropriate and the context was used

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! bug_report_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- 🕮 Read our guide about submitting issues: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Submitting-Bugs-and-Suggestions -->
<!-- 🔎 Search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- 🧪 Test using the latest Insiders build to see if your issue has already been fixed: https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders/ -->
<!-- 💡 Instead of creating your report here, use 'Report Issue' from the 'Help' menu in VS Code to pre-fill useful information. -->
<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->



- VS Code Version: 1.104.2
- OS Version: Pop!_OS 22.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create the following files:
   ```jsonc
   // ~/.config/Code/User/settings.json
   {
     "[json]": {
       "editor.defaultFormatter": "esbenp.prettier-vscode"
     },
     "[json][javascript]": {
       "editor.defaultFormatter": "dprint.dprint"
     },
   }
   ```

   ```jsonc
   // path/to/project/.vscode/settings.json
   {
     "[json][javascript][typescript]": {
       "editor.defaultFormatter": "biomejs.biome"
     },
   }
   ```
2. Format a JSON file in the workspace

Normally project-local settings take precedence over user settings. This works, because JSON keys are unique. Language setting overrides however, can be combined. This creates multiple conflicting sections. User settings may or may not take precedence.

In this example, Prettier is used. If the `[json]` section was removed, I honestly couldn’t tell.

Personally I think it’s a bad idea to commit editor settings in a project. However, other people do this. They may not be aware that their settings only work for their editor setup.

This is a confusing problem I run into now and then, but I don’t have a proposal to fix it.

body:
After our get-together, @justschen and I chatted briefly on list/tree usage in Chat and its cumbersomeness. I've always found strange that we're using our list/tree widgets for Chat since chat histories aren't nearly tall enough for it to warrant virtualizing and paying all that overhead engineering cost that comes with those widgets. Furthermore, none of the focus/selection/open/click behaviors and styles are really necessary in that view.

Should we just drop it?

Interested in other people's thoughts, mostly @roblourens, @connor4312, @jrieken, @alexdima

comments.body:
I think using a list view for it is okay but our current representation of having the entire request and responses as a single list item is not ideal. This presents weird focus behavior and also some challenges for accessibility. I think each 'sub part' should be its own list item with a standard list item renderer.

> chat histories aren't nearly tall enough for it to warrant virtualizing

Some people use one big chat for everything in their repo. I don't think we can assume that virtualization is something we won't need, especially with Matt's webview renderers for output (that I will adopt for MCP-UI at some point)

labels.name: debt
labels.description: Code quality issues

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

title: Chat: Consider dropping list/tree for chat view

body:
when `.code-profile` file includes github copilot or github copilot chat extension (I'm not sure with one it is), it's impossible to import that `.code-profile` profile as a profile since as soon as time comes for vscode to auto install extensions, when it reaches github copilot or github copilot chat it just crashes whole import process.

- Copilot Chat Extension Version:
0.31.3
- VS Code Version:
1.104.2
e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92
x64
- OS Version:
ubuntu 24.04.3
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode):
extension itself and vscode profile.
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet):
not related to models themselves, but extension itself.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. try to import `.code-profile` profile file with github copilot or github copilot extensions.
2. It crashes during installation of github copilot or github copilot

I was able to resolve this by asking ai to remove github copilot and github copilot

body:
JSONC mode supports trailing commas but it has shown a warning for them [since this commit](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/a7def72d9e5d3e6a04a2c28e1da7f00d4ab9f61b). The stated reason [in this comment](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/194550#issuecomment-1748476991) is that although VSCode supports trailing commas for settings files, Typescript doesn't support them for `tsconfig.json` (but it does support comments).

Also [here](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/194550#issuecomment-1748476991) @aeschli says

> JSONC is not a standard and we only want to promote it for our own setting files and for some selected configuration files.

However, people *really really* want JSON with comments and you guys accidentally created a de facto standard for it. There are at least two attempts to formalise that, [here](https://jsonc.org/) and [here](https://github.com/stephenberry/JSONC) (and [this totally different format](https://github.com/komkom/jsonc) which was also unwisely named "JSONC" by its author).

Neither of those allow trailing commas (but IMO they should). But more importantly if you look at [the list of libraries that actually parse "JSONC"](https://github.com/DecimalTurn/JSONC/issues/10#issuecomment-3346673830), half of them support trailing commas, sometimes unconditionally.

So I feel like the warning is a bit heavy handed and should be disabled by default, seeing as half the time it is wrong.

I think you could blacklist files that are *known* to not support trailing commas, e.g. `tsconfig.json` and show an error there instead. It might even be worth having two modes to make the behavior a bit clearer. I think I saw someone suggest JSONCC or something like that.

comments.body: the current working is to assign a schema with the `allowsTrailingCommas` option enabled

Because there are some file formats out there that support comments but no trailing commas (tsconfig.json), we decided to warn on trailing commas by default to avoid  'corrupt' files (better safe than sorry)
But for the file formats that allow trailing commas (e.g. the VS Code settings files) we can turn off that check via a setting in the schema,
See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/237258#issuecomment-2574854653
What about having two modes though? JSONC and JSONCC?

We have no plans for that, but you could add that as an extension.
See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/237258#issuecomment-2574854653 how you can customize the JSONC mode for  your files

Would you accept a PR for it though? This only really works if it comes by default. There's not much point if I make a third party extension that nobody uses or if I add a custom `fileMatch` that nobody else has.

short answer no
long answer maybe in the distant future
Why though?

Sorry I would not accept such a PR. We don't want to add another mode. We have no need on our side as it's already possible to configure which JSONC files support trailing commas.
And as said, we see JSONC as an internal file format and don't want to promote it.

Unfortunate.

> And as said, we see JSONC as an internal file format and don't want to promote it.

Way too late for that I'm afraid.

title: Please stop the auto next suggestion.

body:
When using MCP sampling with createMessage, operations that take longer than ~60 seconds fail with error code 32001 (timeout error)
This timeout value is not exposed in any configuration settings
Developers have no way to adjust the timeout duration for their specific use cases
Operations that legitimately require more than 60 seconds to complete will always fail

McpError: MCP error -32001: Request timed out

comments.body: We do not implement timeouts (or anything that generates a 32001 error code) in VS Code. This is likely something your SDK or network stack implements.

Type: Bug copilot is not understanding the question & just returning the same output each time AND THIS IS HAPPENING ONLY FOR A SINGLE REPO, in other repos its working fine OUTPUT: I can see this is a mobile testing infrastructure repository with Android testing capabilities, various automation tools, and deployment configurations. Based on the files I can see, this appears to be a comprehensive mobile testing platform with support for Appium, device management, proxy configurations, and various testing frameworks. Let me explore the repository structure to better understand the codebase and help you with any specific questions or tasks you might have. Read README.md, lines 1 to 50 Summarized conversation history I can see you're working in a mobile testing workspace with a complex structure that includes Android testing tools, BrowserStack integration, and various automation components. How can I help you with this project today? Some things I can assist with: Code Analysis & Development: Help with Ruby scripts, Android automation, or any other code in the project Testing & Quality Assurance: Work with the testing frameworks (Detox, Espresso, Maestro, Playwright, etc.) DevOps & Deployment: Help with the Jenkins pipeline, Docker setup, or deployment configurations Documentation: Review or improve the project documentation Project Structure: Navigate and understand the codebase organization What would you like to work on? Feel free to ask about specific files, features, or tasks you'd like to accomplish. body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes Version: 1.104.2 (user setup) Commit: e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92 Date: 2025-09-24T11:21:37.073Z (4 days ago) Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12404162 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 In the latest version, the context menu option "Open Externally" is missing. Before: After: I've never had any extension that will open the file externally Steps to Reproduce: 1. Right click to file 2. search for Open Externally

comments.body: I don't think VS Code ever provided this command (I went back and checked the source code from versions 1.102 and 1.101). One of your installed extensions must have contributed this without you noticing.

labels.name: *caused-by-extension

title: Open Externally Context Menu missing

body: I noticed that + isn't shown on empty chats, which makes logical sense but may not be best UX since it's a learning opportunity when a user opens chat for the first time and explores it.

comments.body: It makes sense to me to hide it, since it's not going to do anything in that scenario. I think someone new could easily be confused if they expect it to open a new tab or something like that. Looks like this was @eli-w-king

From @joaomoreno 
> The current behavior goes against our UX guidelines: we should not hide the + action. At worse, we could disable it. But IMO if it's a noop on a new chat, I'd just leave it enabled, to reduce UI overload on the user. 

and I agree with this ^

> But IMO if it's a noop on a new chat, I'd just leave it enabled, to reduce UI overload on the user.

I don't understand this sentence, did he mean disabled?

@roblourens he's talking about the original behavior of the + where it would appear enabled and just be a noop. "overload" here is that the button being enabled/disabled is stateful, and personally disabled buttons are super confusing because they usually don't tell user why they're disabled
Restored 'Add chat' button while chat history is enabled. PR here: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/269620
It tells the user that the button is not a valid action in this state, which is less confusing than a button that doesn't do anything IMO
Does this need labels/milestone @eli-w-king?

labels.name: ux
labels.description: User experience issues

Please look at the following meta issue: https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/253126. Please refer to that issue for updates and discussions. Feel free to open a new issue if you think this is a different problem.

title: Error on conversation request

body:
@chrmarti pointed that time to first byte when using Electron net module was higher compared to Node.js network api. The test case pretty much was an http2 server streaming 1 byte sequentially for n iterations (https://github.com/chrmarti/http-client-tests), it was obvious from the results that as n grew larger there was some sort of buffering in Electron which was not visible with Node.js.

A deeper look at how the response body is streamed across processes in chromium made sense of this buffering,

Firstly, whichever process (browser, utility, renderer) a network request is made via appropriate web or Electron api can be thought of as the client process. The requests are eventually forwarded to a dedicated process (network service) that makes the actual OS call.

For the above http2 response streaming case, here are how the buffers get setup

1) A read buffer of 8KB to read records from SSL - https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:net/spdy/spdy_session.cc;l=1956-1960;
2) A ring buffer based on shared memory to transfer response body between the network and client processes. The size of the ring buffer can be either 512KB or 2MB depending on the type of loader used. In the case of Electron net, they are backed by `network::URLLoader` which uses 2MB ring buffer https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/public/cpp/loading_params.cc;l=31-48
3) Finally, a buffer to transfer data between 1 and 2 called `NetToMojoPendingBuffer` https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:services/network/public/cpp/net_adapters.cc;l=32-48;. Can be thought of as a view in the ring buffer that gets locked at a time to write the data from the low level network call, completion of the write signals the read end of the mojo pipe (client process) to start reading. For more context on Mojo data pipes, refer to this doc under `Creating Data pipes` section https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:mojo/public/c/system/README.md

The [SSL_Read](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:net/spdy/spdy_session.cc;l=1909-1924) loop will yield when the read becomes blocked or if a certain [read limit is exceeded](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:net/spdy/spdy_session.h;l=85-88), currently it is 32KB or read for more than 20ms. These are then queued into the buffer from Step 3 whose default is 64KB. As n becomes greater than 8192 in the test case we are going to see increased time to first byte as the buffer in step 3 queues data till the read loop yields.

For n=150000, the test case shows 2.3seconds for the ttfb

```
Utility process stdout: Response stats: {
  "useElectronFetch": true,
  "useHttp2": true,
  "chunks": {
    "18928": 1,
    "65536": 2
  },
  "ttfb": {
    "2394": 1
  }
}
```

Adjusting the buffer size in Step 3 to 8KB reduces this number to 371ms in favor of more read operations

```
Utility process stdout: Response stats: {
  "useElectronFetch": true,
  "useHttp2": true,
  "chunks": {
    "1": 2,
    "2": 1,
    "6": 1,
    "10": 2,
    "11": 1,
    "12": 1,
    "151": 1,
    "257": 1,
    "265": 1,
    "266": 1,
    "269": 1,
    "1273": 1,
    "8192": 13,
    "8193": 2,
    "8194": 1,
    "8195": 2
  },
  "ttfb": {
    "371": 1
  }
}
```

title: weffwfwfr

body:
Type: Bug The Copilot Agent should execute a series of commands within the same terminal session to maintain context, especially for commands that depend on a persistent state like an activated virtual environment. The agent should either: Reuse the existing terminal session it started. Be capable of reactivating the correct environment in the new terminal before executing the command. Actual Behavior: The Copilot Agent launches a new, isolated terminal for each successive command. This causes the loss of context (specifically, the activated Python environment), leading to execution failures. Additional Context: This issue is most prominent in Python development workflows but could affect any scenario where sequential terminal commands rely on a shared state or activated environment. The core problem appears to be the agent's inability to persist context across multiple terminal invocations. This requires me to manually copy and paste commands into the original terminal, which defeats the purpose of the agent mode. To figure out a bit more why this happens, please follow along:

#### Enable trace logging

* Open the Command Palette (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Trace`, click the *double* check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (enables trace logging as the default)

_Now wait for the issue to happen or trigger it..._

#### Getting the logs

* Open the Command Palette again (<kbd>cmd</kbd>/<kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>p</kbd>)
* Run the `Output: Show Output Channels...` command
* Choose `GitHub Authentication`
* Copy and paste the contents of what opens in the panel in this issue (if the contents is too large, you may need to upload it as a file)

Do these steps again for these other output channels:
* `GitHub Copilot Chat`
* `GitHub Copilot`

#### Reverting trace logging (optional)

When we're done here, to revert the log level back to the default:
* Open the Command Palette
* Run the `Developer: Set Log Level...` command
* To the right of `Info`, click the double check mark button. ✔️ ✔️ (to set the default back to info)

title: Can't stop Copilot Agent

body:
Continued from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/262756

Current state: set `"github.copilot.chat.advanced.claudeCode.enabled": true` and use from the chat sessions view

### Required for a basically usable experience
- Needs all the polish of different tool confirmation types, eg for terminals, with the same auto-approve logic
- Track edits
	- Apply our logic for allowing edits inside the workspace
	- But requiring confirmation for certain files (how to do this when the agent is editing the file?)
	- The agent editing files that are unsaved in vscode?

### Polish
- `/ide` context eg open files, tools to integrate with editor
  - Not sure if it should be based on us implementing the websocket protocol that CC uses or just installing the official CC extension
- Support multi-root via `additionalDirectories`
- Show background bash shells (`/bashes`)?
- Slash commands
  - `/compact`
  - `/memory`
- Manage agents, show subtasks. The user's configured agents are used by the sdk
- Start and manage a claude code agent on a different directory (eg worktree)
- Support custom `/` commands
- Test all types of vscode attachments
- Enable mcp servers configured in vscode
- Fully use streaming mode to use same CC process across requests, timing out at some point
- Align Bash command approval with vscode's auto-approval as configured by the user
- Show tool invocation progress in a nicer way (currently tool calls only show up when done)
- Linkify response
- Show terminal output

## Open questions
- How integrated is this experience with vscode? Is it totally aligned with how the vscode agent is configured, or is it just "claude code in vscode", configured as CC typically is? 
- Session storage- we read sessions from `~/.claude`, but the vscode requests have some of their own metadata that I don't have anywhere to store, so things like attachments on the original request can't be restored https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/264816
- Conversation summaries don't work because it looks like claude code doesn't respect the `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` env var for these requests
- We redirect haiku requests to gpt-4o-mini but it has a much lower prompt token limit than expected, so these sometimes fail
- Branding, icons, etc
- Our Claude 4 has a much smaller context window than what Claude Code assumes. We adjust the reported token usage so that auto-compact will be triggered correctly, but it's still a bit off because after compaction, the conversation gets resized so a size that Claude Code thinks is safe, but is actually still a bit close to our context limit.

title: run_task didn't wait for vscode build tasks to complete

body:
## Main issue
Version info:

``` Version: 1.105.0-insider (user setup) Commit: ceb07bd32d461c726db89293f007f4acb700df6c Date: 2025-09-29T05:02:16.711Z Electron: 37.3.1 ElectronBuildId: 12404162 Chromium: 138.0.7204.235 Node.js: 22.18.0 V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0 OS: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 ```

When configuring Copilot prompt and chatmode files in a repo using VSCode, the default settings does not include nested directories. This behavior differs from how instructions are discovered. I am working on a codified solution where Copilot customization files (instructions, prompts, chatmodes) can be maintained centrally and synced out to repos (of a given type, using custom properties) while still allowing local flexibility. This solution relies on using subfolders. ```plaintext .github/ ├─instructions/ # AI agent guidance and patterns │ ├─organization/ # Organization-managed instruction patterns (automated sync) │ │ ├─main.instructions.md # Core organizational framework guidelines │ │ └─{Language}/ # Language/technology-specific framework patterns │ │ ├─main.instructions.md # Style guide and core instructions │ │ └─{context}.instructions.md # Specialized context instructions │ └─repository/ # Repository-managed instruction overrides (manual) │ ├─main.instructions.md # Repository context and specific rules │ └─{Language}/ # Repository-specific language customizations │ ├─main.instructions.md # Repository language patterns │ └─{context}.instructions.md # Repository context overrides ├─prompts/ # Reusable prompt templates │ ├─organization/ # Organization-managed prompts (automated sync) │ │ └─{prompt-files} # Standard organization prompt templates │ └─repository/ # Repository-managed prompts (manual) │ └─{prompt-files} # Project-specific prompt templates └─chatmodes/ # Specialized conversation contexts ├─organization/ # Organization-managed chat modes (automated sync) │ └─{chatmode-files} # Standard organization chat modes └─repository/ # Repository-managed chat modes (manual) └─{chatmode-files} # Project-specific chat modes ``` ### Why this is important There is currently no good codified approach for how organizations and enterprises can scale common Copilot customizations. The organization structure for managing this is not great, as it relies on user settings rather than discoverable files. In an **enterprise context**, this matters because: - Large enterprises often operate multiple **GitHub organizations** (similar to projects in Azure DevOps). - Each organization may represent a **product group** or a **technology community**. - **Technology communities** may want to provide shared instructions, prompts and chatmodes for developers/contributors of their language or stack. - **Product teams** would combine those with product-specific customizations in their repositories. Even in an **open source (non-enterprise) context**, technology community (GitHub organization) would benefit from centralizing Copilot customization in one place, while still letting individual repositories adopt or extend those customizations as needed. For these scenarios to work, discovery of chatmodes and prompts needs to behave consistently with instructions. Without support for nested folders by default, it becomes difficult to cleanly separate centrally managed (organization-level) files from locally managed (repository-level) ones. ### Default configurations ```json "chat.instructionsFilesLocations": { ".github/instructions": true }, "chat.modeFilesLocations": { ".github/chatmodes": true }, "chat.promptFilesLocations": { ".github/prompts": true } ```` With the above defaults (as shipped with VSCode Insider), `instructions` correctly discover files in nested folders as per design, i.e. path-filtered instructions. However, `prompts` and `chatmodes` only discovers files placed directly under `.github/prompts` and ignores any subfolders. ### Example * `.github/prompts/foo.prompt.md` <- discovered * `.github/prompts/nested/bar.prompt.md` <- not discovered ### Current workaround Users need to explicitly add a glob pattern to their configuration: ```json "chat.promptFilesLocations": { ".github/prompts/**/*.prompt.md": true } ``` ### Expected behavior For consistency with `instructions` and `chatmodes`, `prompt` discovery should also include nested directories by default. ### Impact This inconsistency can cause confusion for users who organize prompts in subfolders (e.g., by domain, framework, or role), expecting them to be discovered in the same way as instructions and chatmodes. It also prevents organizations and communities from fully exploring scalable file-based management patterns for Copilot customizations in both enterprise and open source setups.

comments.body: I can't reproduce. The same code is used to find prompt/modes and instruction files. By default only the `instructions`, `chatmodes` and `prompts` folders are searched, no subfolders. Maybe the LLM agent found the nested instructions by searching the file system? Or you referenced them somewhere? Note that the instructions in `subfolders` are not listed.
Note that you can set the `promptFilesLocations` setting in your workspace settings. No need to change the default of VS Code to enable your scenario.
We want to stick with the current default for now. As mentioned, change the setting in your workspace so all users of the repo will get the nested instruction files as well.

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.2 - OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10 Commit: e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92 Steps to Reproduce --- 1. Lets have a code: ```html Document ``` 2. Hover mouse cursor over `DataTransfer` constructor. ER --- Will be displayed JSDoc with description text and link to online docs (mdn) from `lib.dom.d.ts` as it is declared: ```js /** * The **`DataTransfer`** object is used to hold any data transferred between contexts, such as a drag and drop operation, or clipboard read/write. * * [MDN Reference](https://developer.mozilla.org/docs/Web/API/DataTransfer) */ interface DataTransfer { ... ``` AR --- No JSDoc description and no link to online docs (mdn)

comments.body:
The hover is powered by the TypeScript `d.ts` files.
It looks like the constructor for `DataTransfer` has no JS doc attached (the interface definition does)

https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/blob/e350126ab989f463aac638555e430dcd55421d0b/src/lib/dom.generated.d.ts#L9485

Please file the issue against https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript

@aeschli I tested this via TS playground and it works in pure TS: [here](https://www.typescriptlang.org/play/?#code/FAYw9gdgzgLgBAE3gXjhApgdzgEQIYx4AqATntAGbokAUAlANzBA) Problems still exists --- **So this is problem is in VS Code for `html` file format** as for JS/TS files format it works: **JS** **TS** One more time for `html` --- @aeschli so, please, **reopen issue** and dont close issues if you not checked it properly @mjbvz please, help with this to not lost

Probably we can improve the way the hover is computed for JavaScript embedded in HTML.
Happy if someone want to look into it....

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

- Copilot Chat Extension Version: GitHub Copilot Chat  v0.32.2025092602 (pre-release) 
- VS Code Version: Version: 1.105.0-insider (Universal)
   Commit: 588279f5b77b10bc41f3f8bb864350814e3823f4
   Date: 2025-09-26T05:05:03.410Z
   Electron: 37.3.1
   ElectronBuildId: 12404162
   Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
   Node.js: 22.18.0
   V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
- OS Version: OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0
- Feature (e.g. agent/edit/ask mode): Agent Mode
- Selected model (e.g. GPT 4.1, Claude 3.7 Sonnet): Sonnet 4.0, GPT-5-Codex
- Logs: to come next time it happens to me

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Interact with agent in an extended session
2. After a while, agent stops seeing terminal output and starts running diagnostics to figure out why it can't see terminal output any longer. This happens in Sonnet 4 and GPT-5-Codex so far, so it doesn't seem to be model specific. 

The only remedy is to start a new chat session.

I have ZSH with OhMyZSH

```
➜ echo $ZSH_VERSION
5.9
➜ omz version
master (763aab3)
```

comments.body:
Asking agent mode about this problem, it reports:

Potential Issues in Your Setup

1. Spaceship Theme Conflicts: Your spaceship theme has its own precmd/preexec hooks that might interfere with VS Code's integration
2. Hook Ordering: The order of hooks matters - if Spaceship runs after VS Code's hooks, it could disrupt the communication
3. ANSI Escape Handling: Complex prompts like Spaceship can sometimes interfere with escape sequence parsing

I've switched to a simpler theme to see if `spaceship` is the problem. The other thing I wonder about is that when generating test cases, agent mode often codes things with pretty ANSI terminal coloring and could potentially be interfering as well.

This will happen if your shell startup scripts conflict with shell integration. See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Terminal-Issues#prompt-input-detection. You can hover the terminal tab, click `Show Details` and provide a screenshot also. Like: We're going to try to improve this experience, tracked here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268339.

Happy coding!

title: В панели ПРОБЛЕМЫ пишет что в рабочей области проблем не обнаружено

body:
**Describe the bug**
When I open GitHub Copilot Chat and ask any question using the `@workspace` command, my TypeScript (TS) server immediately crashes. This disrupts all TypeScript language features in my editor until I restart the TS server or reload the window.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open a project with TypeScript enabled in VS Code.
2. Activate GitHub Copilot Chat.
3. Type a question in Copilot Chat and prefix it with `@workspace` (e.g., `@workspace list all React components`).
4. Observe that the TypeScript server crashes shortly after submitting the query.

**Expected behavior**
The TS server should remain stable and continue to provide language features, regardless of Copilot Chat usage.



**Environment**
- OS: Ubuntu 24.04.3 LTS
- VS Code version: 1.104.2 | e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92 | x64
- Copilot Chat extension version: 0.31.3
- Workspace TypeScript version: 5.8.3
- Node.js version: 24.0.0

**Additional context**
- The crash happens regardless of the question asked with `@workspace`.
- Restarting the TS server temporarily resolves the issue until `@workspace` is used again.

comments.body: This bug should be fixed in TypeScript 5.9+. Please try updating to the latest Typescript release and let me know if you're still seeing the issue

body:
Type: Bug https://github.com/The-Medusa-Initiative I am a pro member but the Co-Pilot keeps saying; I'm sorry for the confusion and frustration—this seems like a potential issue with plan recognition or activation in your GitHub Copilot setup. Even though you mention being a PRO member with a business plan (which should include access to these features), the system is currently restricting the Java upgrade tools. Here are a few steps you can try to resolve this: Verify your plan: Double-check your GitHub Copilot subscription in your GitHub account settings (go to Settings > Copilot). Ensure it's active and shows as "Business" or "Enterprise". If it's listed as "Free" or "Pro" without business features, you may need to upgrade or contact billing support. Sign out and back in: Try signing out of GitHub in VS Code (or your IDE) and signing back in. This can sometimes refresh the plan status. Contact GitHub Support: If the plan looks correct, reach out to GitHub Support directly. You can do this via the GitHub website (Help > Contact Support) or through your business admin if it's managed via an organization. Mention the error message and your plan details—they can investigate why the pro features aren't unlocking. Alternative approaches: In the meantime, since your current project appears to be C++ (based on the CMakeLists.txt and file structure), and there are no user-written Java files (only SDL library Java bindings), you might not need Java upgrade tools here. If you do have a separate Java project, you could try upgrading JDK manually: Download the latest LTS JDK (Java 21) from Adoptium or Oracle. Set JAVA_HOME and update PATH in your system environment variables. For project-specific upgrades, use Maven/Gradle commands like mvn versions:use-latest-versions or similar. If you provide more details about your setup or the specific Java project you're trying to upgrade, I can help with manual steps or other tools! body:
Repro:

- Open a file
- Put the cursor somewhere with multiple levels of sticky scroll
- Scroll down such that the cursor is behind sticky scroll
- Type, 🐛 the cursor will not be revealed

I've hit this a few times when I press ctrl+d to select something, and scroll down to keep checking when I only want to replace a subset of the matching items.
title: Typing when cursor is obscured behind sticky scroll does not reveal when typing

body:
## Bug Description

When using GitHub Copilot's file creation functionality in VS Code, the created file content appears to be duplicated - the same content is written to the file twice, resulting in redundant and malformed files.

## Environment
- VS Code Version: [Current stable version]
- Operating System: macOS
- Extensions: GitHub Copilot, GitHub Copilot Chat
- Shell: zsh

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Use GitHub Copilot to create a new file with specific content
2. The tool appears to execute successfully
3. Open the created file to inspect its contents

## Expected Behavior

The file should be created with the specified content exactly once, resulting in a well-formed, correctly structured file.

## Actual Behavior

The file is created with the same content duplicated - the entire content appears twice in the file, making it malformed and unusable without manual editing.

## Impact

This significantly impacts developer productivity as:
- Files need manual cleanup after creation
- Code structure becomes malformed 
- Automated workflows may fail due to duplicate content
- Time is wasted on manual correction of what should be automated tasks

## Example

When requesting creation of a Python file with class definitions, the resulting file contains:

```python
class MyClass:
    def method(self):
        pass

class MyClass:  # Duplicate content
    def method(self):
        pass
```

Instead of the expected single instance of the class.

## Frequency

This appears to happen consistently when using Copilot's file creation features, suggesting a systematic issue rather than an intermittent bug.

## Workaround

Currently, users must manually edit every file created through Copilot to remove the duplicate content, which defeats the purpose of automated file generation.

## Additional Context

This issue affects:
- Python files (confirmed)
- Potentially other file types created through Copilot
- All file creation operations through the Copilot interface

The duplication appears to be at the content level, not a display issue, as the duplicated content persists when the file is saved and reopened.
title: GitHub Copilot file creation results in duplicated content within created files

body:
## Bug Description

When executing long-running terminal commands through VS Code's integrated terminal, the entire VS Code interface becomes unresponsive and blocks other operations, including:

- Cannot execute additional terminal commands
- Cannot use GitHub Copilot tools/extensions
- General UI responsiveness issues

## Environment
- VS Code Version: [Current stable version]
- Operating System: macOS
- Shell: zsh
- Extensions: GitHub Copilot (and related extensions)

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Execute a long-running command in VS Code's integrated terminal (e.g., `pyenv install 3.10.17` which involves downloading and compiling Python)
2. While the command is running, try to:
   - Execute another command in a different terminal tab
   - Use GitHub Copilot tools or extensions
   - Perform other VS Code operations

## Expected Behavior

Long-running terminal commands should not block other VS Code functionality. Users should be able to:
- Open new terminal sessions and execute commands
- Continue using extensions and tools
- Maintain normal VS Code responsiveness

## Actual Behavior

VS Code becomes largely unresponsive during long-running terminal operations, effectively blocking the entire development workflow.

## Impact

This severely impacts developer productivity, especially during environment setup tasks, package installations, or any operations that involve network downloads or compilation processes.

## Workaround

Currently, users must wait for long-running commands to complete before being able to use VS Code normally, or resort to external terminal applications.

## Additional Context

This issue is particularly problematic for development workflows that involve:
- Python environment management (pyenv, conda)
- Package installations (npm, pip, cargo)
- Build processes
- Any network-dependent operations

The terminal should ideally run in a non-blocking manner, allowing users to continue working while background processes complete.

body: Type: Bug サーバ起動を実行するコマンドを（cd XXX && npm run dev）起動すると最初の1文字が削られた状態でコマンド発行される（d XXX && npm run dev） 失敗し続ける。これでトークン消費されるの？ Extension version: 0.31.3 VS Code version: Code 1.104.2 (e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92, 2025-09-24T11:21:37.073Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

It keeps failing. Does this consume tokens?

title: Cnat continue

body:
Refs: #253945

- [x] macOS @ulugbekna
- [x] linux @joshspicer
- [x] windows @jo-oikawa

Complexity: 2


[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23268719%0A%0A&assignees=Tyriar)

---

There's a new set of settings `chat.tools.terminal.terminalProfile.<os>` that allows the shell launched by Copilot to be configured. This setting is inspired by the "automation profile" setting which does something similar but for tasks and debug.

Please test:

- All the properties work as expected for your OS
- On Windows, make sure you can set cmd and it does NOT revert to pwsh ([this is only expected when cmd is the terminal's overall default profile](https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_104#_improved-terminal-support))

comments.body: /gifPlease

Thanks for reporting this issue! Unfortunately, it's hard for us to understand what issue you're seeing. Please help us out by providing a screen recording showing exactly what isn't working as expected. While we can work with most standard formats, `.gif` files are preferred as they are displayed inline on GitHub. You may find https://gifcap.dev helpful as a browser-based gif recording tool.

If the issue depends on keyboard input, you can help us by enabling screencast mode for the recording (`Developer: Toggle Screencast Mode` in the command palette). Lastly, please attach this file via the GitHub web interface as emailed responses will strip files out from the issue.

Happy coding!

title: Unneeded code left behind after revisions

body:
Type: Bug ### Description When Copilot is generating a response in the chat panel, clicking on one of my previous user messages immediately cancels the ongoing response. This makes it difficult to review or prepare edits to earlier prompts without interrupting the active session. ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Open the Copilot chat in VS Code. 2. Enter a prompt and wait for Copilot to start generating a response. 3. While Copilot is still responding, click on one of your previous chat bubbles (a user message) in order to review it. ### Expected Behavior I should be able to click on my previous prompts to view or prepare to edit them without canceling the active response. The response should only be canceled if I actually make an edit to the previous prompt. If I cancel out of editing without making changes, the active session should continue uninterrupted. ### Actual Behavior As soon as I click on a previous chat bubble while Copilot is still responding, the response is immediately canceled, even though I have not made any changes. ### Impact This disrupts the workflow when trying to review or cross-check prior prompts while waiting for Copilot to finish. It forces me to wait until the current response completes before reviewing earlier entries, or risk losing the response. ### Suggested Improvement Allow previous chat bubbles to become editable while a response is active, but do not cancel the active session until an actual edit is made and submitted. comments.body: This will happen if your shell startup scripts conflict with and cause shell integration to fail to activate. See https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/wiki/Terminal-Issues#prompt-input-detection. An example of when this occurs is if you have `powerlevel10k` active. Please try commenting out various things in your startup scripts to find the culprit. You can hover the terminal tab, click `Show Details` and provide a screenshot also. Like: We're going to try to improve this experience, tracked here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/268339.

title: Agente paralizado

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates -->
<!-- Please attach logs to help us diagnose your issue -->

### 🐞 Issue Summary

When using Copilot Chat in **agent mode**, commands that depend on an activated Python virtual environment (VENV) fail to execute properly—even though the VENV is already activated in the VS Code terminal.

---

### 💻 Environment Details

- **Copilot Chat Extension Version**: 0.31.3  
- **VS Code Version**: 1.104.1 (user setup)  
- **OS**: Windows 11 64-bit (Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100)  
- **Feature Used**: Agent mode  
- **Model Selected**: Claude Sonnet 4  
- **Logs**: None available  

---

### 🔁 Steps to Reproduce

1. Open VS Code and activate a Python virtual environment (VENV).
2. In agent mode, ask Copilot to run a command that requires the VENV (e.g., importing a module installed only in the VENV).

---

### ✅ Expected Behavior

The command should execute successfully, as it would in a regular VS Code terminal session where `activate.ps1` is automatically run:

```powershell
PS C:\Users\user\Documents\Project> & C:/Users/user/Documents/Project/VirualENV/Scripts/Activate.ps1
(VirualENV) PS C:\Users\user\Documents\Project>
```

---

### ❌ Actual Behavior

The command fails with an import error, indicating that the VENV is not recognized or activated in the agent’s context:

```powershell
PS C:\Users\user\Documents\Project> python test.py
❌ Import error: No module named '%module_that_is_only_available_in_VENV%'
```

body:
### Feature Request

Please add support for **context-aware indentation** when pasting Python code into the editor.

### Problem

Currently, when pasting a block of Python code into a function, class, or loop in VSCode, the indentation remains exactly as it was copied—regardless of the surrounding context. This often results in broken indentation that must be manually corrected, which is inconvenient and disruptive to workflow.

### Example

#### Copied code:
```python
for item in collection:
    process(item)
```

#### Pasted inside a function:
```python
def my_function():
    do_something()
    # cursor is here
```

#### Result in VSCode:
```python
def my_function():
    do_something()
    for item in collection:
    process(item)
```

#### Expected behavior:
```python
def my_function():
    do_something()
    for item in collection:
        process(item)
```

### Why It Matters

Python relies heavily on indentation for syntax. Other editors like **PyCharm** automatically adjust pasted code to match the surrounding block structure, reducing the need for manual fixes and minimizing the risk of syntax errors. This feature would significantly improve developer experience and productivity in VSCode.

### What I’ve Tried

- Installing the **Black Formatter** extension
- Enabling `"editor.formatOnPaste": true`
- Enabling `"editor.formatOnSave": true`
- Enabling `"editor.autoIndentOnPaste": true`
- Using `"[python]": { "editor.defaultFormatter": "ms-python.black-formatter" }`
- Running `Format Document` and `Format Selection`
- Installing the **Python Indent** extension

None of these approaches replicate PyCharm’s context-aware indentation behavior.

### Suggested Implementation

When pasting code, VSCode should:
- Detect the indentation level of the surrounding block.
- Re-indent the pasted code to match that level.

This could be an optional setting (e.g., `"editor.contextAwareIndentOnPaste": true`) for users who prefer manual control.
title: Context-aware indentation when pasting Python code

body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

## Environment data

-   VS Code version: 1.104.2
-   Jupyter Extension version : 2025.8.0
-   Python Extension version : 2025.14.0
-   OS Windows  version: Windows 11 Pro 24H2 Build 26100.6584
-   Python version: 3.12.7
-   Type of virtual environment used : venv
-   Jupyter server running: Local

## Expected behaviour

"Don't Save" should clear the cache of changes.

## Actual behaviour

After closing the edited notebook and explicitly asking for the changes to not be saved, VScode still keeps the changes cached somewhere. The notebook file is not changed. But as soon as the file is opened, VSCode adds the unsaved changes back to the notebook.

## Steps to reproduce:

1. Open notebook
2. Edit something (don't save)
3. Close notebook -> "Do you want to save changes..." dialog box appears
4. Click "Don't Save"
5. Reopen notebook -> Changes are still there (even if VSCode is relaunched)

[Create Issue](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/new?template=blank&body=Testing+%23268697%0A%0A&assignees=justschen)

---

## Context
Thinking tokens are now more widely available in GPT-5 for internal users on Responses API and in Codex for all users on Responses API. To show this, there are a few diferent thinking styles that we are iterating on!

## Settings
`chat.agent.thinkingStyle`: collapsed, perItem, fixedScroling.
`github.copilot.chat.responsesApiReasoningEffort`: default or high
`github.copilot.chat.responsesApiReasoningSummary`: detailed
`github.copilot.chat.useResponsesApi`: true

## Test Steps
1. Set `thinkingStyle` to `collapsed`. This is the current default in stable.
2. Ask chat a few questions. You can prompt it additionally with "Think really hard" or "Ultra think" or "make sure to think before replying".
3. Try it our with tool calls, with easy questions, code base search questions, and in general in your day to day.
❗ Make sure to try the built in GPT 5 (preview) model and also Codex ❗ 
4. Verify reasoning parts by setting your Log Level to Trace, and go to Output -> Github Copilot Chat. If you're not seeing reasoning, check to see if the model actually gave us reasoning. Keywords to look for are "reasoning" or "reasoning_summary_text`
5. Repeat steps with `perItem` and `fixedScrolling` styles. 

## Things to Note
- The setting is experimental while we continue to iterate - the default for stable will be the `collapsed` mode, so some of the other styles may not feels as polished!
- There were initial mock ups to hide specific tool calls (ie, searches, reads, list dirs, and more) and group them _with_ thinking in the dropdown, but that will be tabled since there is so much variance in Codex vs. GPT-5.
title: Test: Thinking Tokens in Codex and GPT-5

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes/No

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->
- VS Code Version: 1.104.2
- OS Version:  Pop!_OS 24.04 LTS with the COSMIC desktop (beta) with seahorse (based on Ubuntu 24.04)
- details:
Version: 1.104.2
Commit: e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92
Date: 2025-09-24T11:21:37.073Z
Electron: 37.3.1
ElectronBuildId: 12404162
Chromium: 138.0.7204.235
Node.js: 22.18.0
V8: 13.8.258.31-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 6.16.3-76061603-generic

Steps to Reproduce:

1. from command line : $ code --verbose --vmodule="*/components/os_crypt/*=1"

[10807:0927/181538.578464:VERBOSE1:components/os_crypt/sync/key_storage_util_linux.cc:46] Password storage detected desktop environment: (unknown)
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.669Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Request to start watching: /home/osteck/.config/Code/User (excludes: <none>, includes: <all>, filter: <none>, correlationId: <none>),/home/osteck/.config/Code/User/settings.json (excludes: <none>, includes: <all>, filter: <none>, correlationId: <none>)
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.676Z] Sending env to running instance...
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.677Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Started watching: '/home/osteck/.config/Code/User'
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.677Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Started watching: '/home/osteck/.config/Code/User/settings.json'
[10846:0927/181538.710067:WARNING:sandbox/policy/linux/sandbox_linux.cc:415] InitializeSandbox() called with multiple threads in process gpu-process.
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.717Z] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.718Z] Lifecycle#kill()
[main 2025-09-27T16:15:38.718Z] Lifecycle#onWillShutdown.fire()

2. Desktop environment is detected as unknown. Since  the desktop environment Cosmic is brand new  - beta - no real surprise but the OS is based on Ubuntu 24.04 nonetheless (same keyring manager seahorse)

Looking at https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:base/nix/xdg_util.cc GetDesktopEnvironment() seems to not detect COSMIC although the environment is already registered in the code base

Ran across same issue.
Fresh Arch Linux install with COSMIC Desktop Environment.

Version: 1.104.2
Commit: e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92
Date: 2025-09-26T19:07:51.304Z
Electron: 37.5.1
ElectronBuildId: undefined
Chromium: 138.0.7204.251
Node.js: 22.19.0
V8: 13.8.258.32-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 6.16.8-arch3-1

```bash
$ code --verbose --vmodule="*/components/os_crypt/*=1"
[15249:0928/232444.391477:VERBOSE1:components/os_crypt/sync/key_storage_util_linux.cc:46] Password storage detected desktop environment: (unknown)
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.505Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Request to start watching: /home/dom/.config/Code - OSS/User (excludes: <none>, includes: <all>, filter: <none>, correlationId: <none>),/home/dom/.config/Code - OSS/User/settings.json (excludes: <none>, includes: <all>, filter: <none>, correlationId: <none>)
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.512Z] Sending env to running instance...
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.513Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Started watching: '/home/dom/.config/Code - OSS/User'
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.513Z] [File Watcher (node.js)] Started watching: '/home/dom/.config/Code - OSS/User/settings.json'
[15285:0928/232444.532048:WARNING:sandbox/policy/linux/sandbox_linux.cc:415] InitializeSandbox() called with multiple threads in process gpu-process.
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.569Z] Sent env to running instance. Terminating...
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.569Z] Lifecycle#kill()
[main 2025-09-29T04:24:44.570Z] Lifecycle#onWillShutdown.fire()
```

After doing some more reading in the [VSCode documentation](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/configure/settings-sync#_recommended-configure-the-keyring-to-use-with-vs-code). 

I went ahead and installed the kwallet packages (including the kwalletmanager for a gui), created and opened a wallet. Then following the VSCode doc, added this line to config -- `"password-store": "kwallet5",` and saved. Make sure to unlock the wallet.

Restarted Code, and was able to sign into my account without getting an error.

Possibly an issue with COSMIC's seahorse keyring application not being recognized, but is odd since other applications are able to use it.

title: co-pilot broken consistently for the past week!!!!!

body: I use VS Code to attach to a running container for development. Even though the container's filesystem has already been opened and mounted to the local filesystem, when I use GitHub Copilot's Agent mode to write code, I find that all files generated by the Agent are persisted to the root directory of the C: drive on the host machine, instead of being saved to the opened code path. Even using #codebase doesn't work. What could be the reason for this? Here is my `devcontainer.json`: ``` { "name": "Project DevContainer", "dockerComposeFile": [ "docker-compose.yml", "docker-compose.dev.yml", "docker-compose.extend.yml" ], "service": "backend", "runServices": ["db", "redis", "worker", "frontend", "backend"], "workspaceFolder": "/workspace", "workspaceMount": "source=${localWorkspaceFolder},target=/workspace,type=bind,consistency=cached", title: GitHub Copilot Workspace Path Resolution Bug

body: Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes - VS Code Version: 1.104.2 - OS Version: MacOS Sequioia 15.6.1 - Darwin arm64 24.6.0 Steps to Reproduce: Hello. I'm programming in C# in Visual Studio Code. I'm having issues with Folding when I use Preprocessor Directives. I noticed that this issue doesn't occur when I use Visual Studio Community. It's easily understood with 4 screenshots. These two screenshot belong to Visual Studio Community. As you can see, the functions are folded and the preprocessor directives are hidden inside. Very good. These two screenshot belong to Visual Studio Code. As you can see, there is a mistake. Because Fold indicators should normally be on functions, but when using Preprocessor directives, they are no longer on functions, but on preprocessor directives.As a result, folding doesn't work properly, everything gets all mixed up.

comments.body:
In VS Code you need to install the C# extension to get language aware folding.

What you see in the screenshots is folding based on code indentation. That's the out-of-the-box default as VS Code has not built-in C# parser.

> In VS Code you need to install the C# extension to get language aware folding.
> 
> What you see in the screenshots is folding based on code indentation. That's the out-of-the-box default as VS Code has not built-in C# parser.

C# and the C# Dev Kit extension are installed. Apart from this issue I mentioned, the folding process is working smoothly. I tried every setting related to folding and that could affect folding. But it's still the same.

Make sure that `"editor.foldingStrategy": "auto"` is set
If you have the extensions installed and you see folding ranges that should be improved, file issues against the C# extension

body: Type: Bug After the recent update, the editor stopped "remembering" the position of the left-side panel (e.g., if you make it smaller/bigger - talking about Explorer/Search/etc. panel). If you shrink your panel, close the editor, then reopen it, it resets to its default size. Before the update, it always saved your preferred size of the panel. VS Code version: Code 1.104.2 (e3a5acfb517a443235981655413d566533107e92, 2025-09-24T11:21:37.073Z) OS version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.26100 Modes:

comments.body: /gifplease

Thanks for reporting this issue! Unfortunately, it's hard for us to understand what issue you're seeing. Please help us out by providing a screen recording showing exactly what isn't working as expected. While we can work with most standard formats, `.gif` files are preferred as they are displayed inline on GitHub. You may find https://gifcap.dev helpful as a browser-based gif recording tool.

If the issue depends on keyboard input, you can help us by enabling screencast mode for the recording (`Developer: Toggle Screencast Mode` in the command palette). Lastly, please attach this file via the GitHub web interface as emailed responses will strip files out from the issue.

Happy coding!

Thank you for the reply. I've tried to demonstrate it in a gif. The size of the left-side panel gets reset every time you reopen the folder. If I remember correctly, before it only happened for the folder you open for the first time (then, when you change the size, the editor kept its position).

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/503527e1-d423-4dd7-8fad-b8b3684c765b)

P.S. Perhaps I misunderstand some logic behind this, as in some cases it may keep the size after reopening the folder.

title: update

body:
Type: Performance Issue I’ve noticed a consistent performance issue with Visual Studio Code when GitHub Copilot is enabled. VS Code runs smoothly under normal conditions, but once GitHub Copilot chat is opened, the application begins to hang and experiences noticeable delays in responsiveness. This behavior significantly affects productivity, especially during coding sessions where Copilot is expected to assist in real-time. <!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->

<!-- 🔧 Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

<!-- 🪓 If you answered No above, use 'Help: Start Extension Bisect' from Command Palette to try to identify the cause. -->
<!-- 📣 Issues caused by an extension need to be reported directly to the extension publisher. The 'Help > Report Issue' dialog can assist with this. -->

- VS Code Version: 1.105.0-insider, Commit: 824678f51e533e03ed9edc59e5cf858c47718f42
- OS Version: macOS 15.6 (24G84)

---

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a Markdown file `test.md` with the following content:

   ```markdown
   This is a statement with a footnote.[^1]

   [^1]: This is the footnote definition.
   ```

2. Open the file in VS Code.
3. Check the _Problems_ panel.

---

### Actual Behavior

- A diagnostic appears in the Problems panel:

  ```sh
  No link definition found: '^1'
  ```

- Error metadata:

  ```json
  {
    "resource": "test.md",
    "owner": "markdown",
    "code": "link.no-such-reference",
    "severity": 4,
    "message": "No link definition found: '^1'",
    "origin": "extHost2"
  }
  ```

---

### Expected Behavior

- No error should be reported.
- Footnotes are valid Markdown syntax and should not be flagged as missing references.

---

### Additional Context

- This comes from the **built-in Markdown validation** (`vscode.markdown-language-features`), not a third-party extension.
- Tested with all extensions disabled → still reproducible.
- File type: `*.md` (plain Markdown).
- Reproducible 100% of the time.

comments.body: Forgot to mention: I can make a PR for this once we’ve confirmed this is unintended behavior

Maybe a regression in insider.
I cannot reproduce it with `1.104.2`.
I can repro in `Version: 1.104.0 Commit: f220831ea2d946c0dcb0f3eaa480eb435a2c1260` I Just remember that this might be some experimental settings.

I just located the related settings: `"markdown.validate.referenceLinks.enabled": "warning"` If we ignore this setting, the compliance are gone. but given that `warning` is the default value of this setting, I still think it's a bug.
This do require you to enable `"markdown.validate.enabled": true`
@albertosantini Should I update this context to the description?

Well, I would not change the title.
Let's see what the developers say.

Indeed, I have zero settings (and zero extensions).
Thanks for the troubleshooting.
Duplicate of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-markdown-languageservice/issues/100

I can see a translation error here. I guess movi means "móvi" (or "mueva"), which is the way to say imperative "to move". So it's not "moví" which means "I moved" in simple paste tense (preterite).

seems the translator is not very experienced on this tuteo and voseo problem. E.g. "Dime" is the imperative for "tú" (used in Spain, Mexico, Cuba, and other countries), while "decime" is the imperative for "vos" (used in Argentina, Uruguay, Paraguay, and some parts of Colombia)

Movi is move
I move buttons.

comments.body: @bpasero The action is using the `ChatContextKeys.enabled` context key.

comments.body: /gifPlease

Thanks for reporting this issue! Unfortunately, it's hard for us to understand what issue you're seeing. Please help us out by providing a screen recording showing exactly what isn't working as expected. While we can work with most standard formats, `.gif` files are preferred as they are displayed inline on GitHub. You may find https://gifcap.dev helpful as a browser-based gif recording tool.

If the issue depends on keyboard input, you can help us by enabling screencast mode for the recording (`Developer: Toggle Screencast Mode` in the command palette). Lastly, please attach this file via the GitHub web interface as emailed responses will strip files out from the issue.

Happy coding!

body:
- Edit some files in agent mode
- Don't click keep or stage files
- Commit everything
- After committing, they are edited again because the formatted ran

I don't know how this is coordinated, is it possible to do that before committing? But also then I guess that means you would commit something different than what I reviewed.

I wonder if we can just run the code actions at the end of the chat request when the agent is done?

comments.body: Running save participants at the end of the chat request would kind of solve this case but it doesn't avoid the issue where that can cause later edits in followup requests to start failing due to formatting differences. I think the way to do this is to implement my 'shadow' document idea.

title: Chat-edited files are formatted after committing

body:
Current Behavior
The `multi_replace_string_tool` currently fails when attempting to replace a string that appears multiple times in a file, throwing the error:

```
String replacement failed: Multiple matches found for the text to replace. Multiple exact matches found. Make your search string more specific.
```

Expected Behavior
When multiple occurrences are detected, the tool should provide clearer guidance and support the ability to replace all occurrences.

---

Proposed Solution
Add an optional `replaceAll` parameter to multi_replace_string_in_file tool

Improve error message: When multiple matches are found and `replaceAll` is not set, the error message should:
Suggest using `replaceAll: true` to replace all occurrences

Include line numbers where duplicates were found so the model can verify the edit is valid

Benefits
Reduces friction when making repetitive changes across a file
Provides actionable guidance instead of just failing
title: Add option to `replaceAll` occurances in multi_replace_string tool

I think we should be supporting context, even in the empty state, at least if context was added. I wonder if we should simply transition into the non-empty state to be able to show the context and focus the input box.

Alternatively we just show context even in the welcome state, which I think is the only state we support as long as Copilot is not installed?

Assigning to @bhavyaus for consideration.
